reviewText:
Genre - Fantasy Dungeon Birds Eye Action with Co-op
Okay so I am old enough to played most of the games in the Gauntlet series at their time of release so I pre-ordered this one too.  So what do I think? Well it is a tricky one, I think if you hold it up against the early games in the series this seems the next logical step. Keep to the 4 character format, and make use of co-op (No Diablo players running off like kids on drugs grabbing loot, you are all stuck in the same area!). The 4 characters are varied but only have one primary skill each, I think there should be some options here. There are 3 zones, with 10 levels each. Not a vast amount, but enough until they release some DLC (I guess they plan to, depending on popularity).
You can pay for cosmetic costumes with in-game cash  (why these couldn't add minor stat perks is anyone's guess) and you get relics that act as specials for potions (these can be levelled up and are quite varied). There are also perks you unlock by completing achievements and this is where my main criticism comes in. This is a great idea and would keep you coming back, but their should be more and evenly spaced. You get some for dying once, others for killing thousands of monsters!
I find this game fun, and will play it more in small doses chasing some achievements and harder modes. I completed normal mode in a few hours but then you have hard and unfair to go at, where good teammates are a required (let's hope there are enough active players later on). Plus I should have earned a few more perks by then. I think the price is a bit steep for what you get (I think it should be about 1/3 cheaper). Also as I said at the start it ignores some of the advances made by some of the newer Gauntlet games such as more character choices and a 3D perspective, but for us old boys it mostly ticks the nostalgic box. I give it a thumbs up, but it is a bit of a *shrug* too.

reviewText:
This is the kind of game that I wish that I'd have a Neutral Selection here. Like, not a yes, or no.

I had fun with Gauntlet, don't get me wrong, but if you're buying it, I don't think it holds up. There's a lack of customization options for the user, especially if you're someone who doesn't have 3 friends to play with right away with the game. reviewText:
Gauntlet was an underwhelming experience. Here are some more points that should reinforce my statement:

1. The game is around 5 hours long.

2. There are approximately 4 mobs that you fight that look slightly different every level or so. Combat boils down to destroying summoning stones. You'll be doing this for every single level. Have fun!

3. Relics are utterly useless. Gold doesn't really matter. It doesn't matter if you die either. In fact, you get rewarded for dying. The game is very forgiving.

4. The last boss just sucked. Besides having to wait until you can actually kill him, you get to fight all those fun and varied mobs that you fought all game. The only thing that was missing was even more summoning stones.

5. For me, the game has absolutely no replayability. Once you've done it all, what else is there to do?

6. The ending is a slideshow of 3 pictures with some guy talking in the background. No, really.

7. The characters talk way too much. You'll be hearing the same lines over and over. Enjoy.

reviewText:
A well made remake of the 1980s classic arcade game, that is true to it's predecessor. The game looks and feels really good, I really enjoyed the challenges of each level and the chaotic amount of enemies to burn, slash and shoot. I would say the true content of the game is actually the characters, they each offer a unique way of playing, and because they are so different I feel I can replay the game from scratch without feeling like it is a new game.

However, since the game has been out for a year, I am afraid the community has dwindled, making some of the co-operative features only possible by gaming with friends, which can also add a handicap for solo players, but besides that, I recommend the game if you like a good quick action fantasy game, and it is also a good peek into the past of how games were like for the new generation of gamers, but without the dated pixelated graphics :).

If you want to see how the gameplay is like, click on the link below to see my video review:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OsEExQ4NJSg

reviewText:
I have only played Gauntlet for a short time, but will play some more. Gauntlet is exactly what the store page says it is, a dungeon crawler, RPG, Action type game. I found it rather similar to games like Torchlight, but remember Torchlight is its own game, and you dont have a pet in Gauntlet. But you do get to collect lots of loot, and also Turkeys to eat to rekindle your health as you will be up against hoards of zombies and other creatures, that you will encounter as you move along through the dungeons.The characters you play are rather tiny in the game so i hope you have good eye sight, even though they are tiny, i still had fun playing Gauntlet. Also you can play this game with an Xbox controller quite well. It can be played in single player mode or play with up to 4 players or friends including yourself, I tried  both single and  online and found playing with others was rather more fun except they pinch all the loot and food before i could get to it, so remember to share the food and stash please.

It would be great to join in the game with some friends, and this can be easily set up to do so, if our times allow for convenient game play.

Only negatives I had are :

I had a few issues starting the game as it keeped crashing at the start, but after some persistance and checking the game cache files and a reboot of steam, it ran beautifully. Also to note I have windows 8.1 and the game  ran fine, once it decided to launch, so please dont panic about this, as its all just minor issues i encountered, i just felt i  had to mention this, incase anyone else has a launching issue.

Also game needs more food pickups to be added aswell, as you tend to die pretty quickly, if your not careful.

I will rate this game 8/10.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a co-op game to play with friend Gauntlet is a good choice.

Pros:
~4 player co-op (local, online or both - Yes both)
~4 unique and well balanced characters to choose from.
~Hilarious comments from the Narrator.
~Complete controller support.

Cons:
~The story for the campaign mode is very basic, but kind of what you would expect from Gauntlet.
~Surprisingly computer intensive for what's being displayed on the screen (if FSP are terrible I suggest turning off V-Sync)

Conclusion
Overall this game is a lot of fun, especially if you have the right people to play with. Playing alone is fun too but becomes quite difficult quite quickly depending on which character you are playing as. I suggest you buy this game on sale and try to get the bundle that includes the DLC (for the same price as the game itself on steam).

Notes:
I have only played the Slayer edition with DLC.
I bought this game bundle to play with my brothers.(I didn't buy it to play alone)

reviewText:
Playing this cooperatively with 3 others is great. It keeps the classic Gauntlet formula whilst not trying to overcomplicate things. I can't say I was one of those that had played the original, but playing with those that grew up with it was a good insight.

Personally I don't think it excels in any specific way. Its just a good, solid dungeon crawler. Note that the game takes less then 5 hours to beat, and the game is extremely light on content - even saying that some of the unlocks were really not worth the amount of grinding! Still, Endless and Colosseum modes are nice additions and kept me playing a bit longer.

Grabbed this at a bargain price for £3, and kept me and my friends entertained throughout. A worthy addition to my library.

reviewText:
I have only been playing this game for a few hours or so but I already see a lot of disappointing flaws in the game.

1) If you are looking for a game that is similar to Gauntlet Legends on N64, you will be sorely disappointed. I never played the original arcade version but I did enjoy Legends on N64. This game is nothing like it so please do not spend money expecting a similar experience.

2) Each level is pretty much the same. Each world (or section if you will) has a theme, much like Legends, however each level within that section is pretty much the same. It seems like the developers did not care enough to make each area unique and I was left feeling like I had been playing the same level over and over again. Zero imagination was put into the creation of each level. It is almost like the developers created a program that would spit out some random levels using a small set of textures and models.

3) There is no in game communication for multiplayer. Multiplayer is a disaster. Without communication players cannot coordinate whatsoever. Hey man
recommended: we need it to unlock a secret area!" "Oh secret area eh? I had no idea!" Yeah those conversations never have a chance to happen. If you're a completionist like me
hoursPlayed: you might be matched with someone who likes to run to the next area
voteText: completely oblivious to the small forture waiting on the left hand side of the screen. Which reminds me: There is a sort of doorway that takes you to the next area. If someone were not paying attention and goes through that doorway
helpfulPercent: the game sends everyone to the next area
votesHelpful:
even if the other players know of a plethora of gold toward another part of the screen. Without a communication system there is no way to tell anyone to hold on a second before heading to the next area.

4) The gear system is a joke. So the game boasts that you can modify your character with cool gear etc etc however the selection is dismal and only relics affect your character. Your loadout does NOTHING to improve stats or anything like that. Different outfits are cool and all but why would I spend my hard earned gold on purely cosmetic items (that don't even look good btw) when I can spend the gold on the relics that will actually help my character. I understand that the game just came out but I really hope they make improvements to the gear system because it is terrible right now.

So in summary I was very disappointed in this game and if there were some way I could get my money back then I would. Perhaps my expectations were too high but Gauntlet Legends was a great game for its time and I automatically assumed that they would create something that would feed my nostalgia and provide a great experience at the same time. I will never make that assumption about a game again. A red flag I should have paid attention to from the start was that Warner Brothers and another no-name studio created this game. I am in no way insulting indie developers but I dont think WB or the other company (don't even remember its name) have the experience developing video games necessary to do this game justice.

Please please please do not spend money on this game. Put your money into something

reviewText:
Gauntlet came out today. My review.
The good: Great game play 4 classes with fun abilities making it fun to kill things. The boss fights all have their own challenge to them. You can play 4 player on the same computer. Didn't feel repetitive for different levels.
The bad: Only 4 classes and multiple people can not play the same class. Difficulty did not increase as game progressed. The game was simple with no puzzles. No dazzling graphics. Normally I do not judge on graphics as a negative factor however I expected more game play. There are only 12 levels, 3 of which are just fighting a boss. There are no mini bosses to challenge you no unique monsters or loot. The overpriced gear you can buy is only for visual appearance. There is no findable items as there was in previous games. The relics you buy are also overpriced you will beat the game before you can fully upgrade one relic. The only reason it didn't feel repetitive was because the game was only 4-5 hours long.
Verdict 7/10. Would recommend playing it, would not recommend buying it. It is a arcade game if you have 3 friends you constantly game with, it's only $20, might as well, but don't tell everyone else they should buy it just have them come over. If they opned up the code to the community for custom levels it would be a must have.
voteText: 57 of 104 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So 3 of my friends and myself gave the game a go last night. For $15 bucks (each) and based on past Gauntlet games {Legends and Legacy} we figured it was worth a go. Traditional Gauntlet games get a ton of replay value so the $15 should merit that. In either case let me break into the actual review

Gauntlet starts you off by having you play each class; Warrior, Valkyrie, Elf/Archer and Wizard.

Warrior plays like in the typical hack and slash style. Valkyrie feel very Captain America'esc but still hack and slashy. Elf/Archer plays like a character from Smash TV. Lastly Wizard plays like Invoker from Dota 2 (to elaborate you have 9 spells and based on what elements you combine {Lightning, Fire, Ice} you get a different spell with each spell having its own cooldown). With each unique character you sort of get a different button schema. Where Warrior and Valkyrie (I might need clarification on this) smash buttons. The Elf/Archer and Wizard utilize the right analog.

Once you go through the tutorial you have the ability to start a game or begin a lobby. The lobby system is fantastic. There's no shift tabbing into the steam community to select a person's profile to invite them into a game. You simple click the button to open lobby (for me it was 'Y' on the Xbox control or 'X' on the PS3 based on the conversation software). and it brought up a list of friends currently playing Gauntlet who I could invite. The only gief is I wish it only brought up friends who have / are playing Gauntlet. I still get my full list of steam list friends which I think is silly.

Each selection is unique so can't have two Warriors or Valkyries etc. Once your in the game you have worlds to choose from... there's only 3 worlds with 4 levels so that was sort of a let down from the get go.

Also in the lobby you decide on your difficult. Easy is like a light version of Normal so you have more health and monsters are not as strong. Normal you get infinite number of re-spawns. Hard requires that you have tokens to re-spawn other players and Unfair you simply don't re-spawn and food rarely/never(?) exist. We went with Normal for our play-through.

There's also a shop that sells artifacts however to use the artifacts you must use potions you find in the level. So potions are no longer a generic AOE effect but are used in conjunction with artifacts. Shops items can also be upgraded and few items no longer have the 'one time use' feel. This gives potions sort of a customized feel however ultimately make them useless on boss as no potions spawn on those fights.

Another thing that doesn't exist in the shop now is 'stats'. 'Stats' or any sort of character enhancement is gained by spamming a specific character skill (typically bound to a button or in the Wizards case combine two buttons to make a spell). Other character enhancements (which are called Masteries) are gained through eating food, dying and collecting gold provide a passive bonus rather than active.

As to the actually game play...it felt super linear at first and unfortunately stayed that way for most of the game. There was very few 'whoops we went the wrong way' or 'did we miss something'. If such situations occurred it was a result of a bad camera angle hiding a wall that wasn't visible rather than a puzzle to figure out.

There's of course game elements to try to lighten the mood like players can light barrels of TNT on fire and throw it at friends or destroy food that a friend is about to pick up. There's also preset emotes that players can spam at each other. While were on emotes the characters periodically compliment each other when they get a long kill streak...this is 'cute' at first but due to its frequency gets old fast. The last sort interactive element was the crown which when worn gives the player at the end a gold bonus. However if they get hit the crown drops and another player can pick it up.

Level 1 and 2 of each world was typically presenting the theme. Level 3 was typically a small boss battle arena and level 4 was purely focused on the boss. Bosses were a hybrid of spamming the attack key and figuring out puzzles.

So general flow of the game was 'pick a world' -> 'pick a level' -> 'playthrough it' -> 'return to town' -> 'debating on buying artifacts' -> 'pick a world' repeat.

Now with all that said would I recommend picking up the game... probably not at it's current release price or I would definitely split the $15 bucks among several people and play it via Local. Even then not enough bang for the buck for me to recommend it.

As a group of 4 players we beat the game in about 4.3 hours. It really emphasizes on 'party play' and I could see it getting frustrating solo. There's no 'true' leveling system so you don't really feel the progression. You get a new skill to spam or your cool downs on a spell are reduced but your overall power still feels 'fixed'. As I mentioned before there are 'artifacts' that you can buy with gold earned in game but they are nothing game breaking.

Once you complete the game you do unlock cosmetic items however they require that you use in-game gold to buy them... so your reward for completing the game on a certain difficulty is unlocking an item in which you have to grind the levels you just beat to get the gold to buy the cosmetic item....yeah...no.

On a few minor notes there's a few times where death shows up which leads to comical deaths (Death no longer drains he simple kills you) but is quickly forgotten. There's no alternative classes like Tigress, Jester, Minotaur and etc. After we finished playing we expected that they would be DLC or something silly. Pojo (aka EGG911) is not in the game as well as 'X IS NOW IT' system is out as well.

The novelty and hopefully nostalgia you hope to draw out the game is typically gone after the first few hours. At its core it took what made the Gauntlet series unique and made it feel like a generic hack and slash.

Oh one last thing before I close this out...the soundtrack is okay but nothing stellar or to write home about.

Edits below (due to comments section limitation of 1,000 characters or less)

Response to Jareth Gawain on 09/28/2014:

Correct Jareth Gawain however I find that overall it pulls more aspects from Legends and Legacy then the original Gauntlet.

The original Gauntlet arcade aspects that differed it from other hack and slash/beat-'em-up arcade games at that time was the concept of a time limit.  Players health totals constantly dropped and there weren't many/any titles prior to this that forced players to find a way to conclude the level in an effective manner.  This game mechanic at the time was complimented by a labyrinth-esc design which futher penalized player for making an incorrect choice for not finding the right way out.  Am I saying that such a mechanic(s) should have been implemented into Gauntlet™?

Absolutely not or rather if they did so perhaps it happens on a higher difficulty.  As I stated I did not play on anything higher than 'Normal' so this may already maybe implemented in the game.  The above game mechanic(s) I didn't feel in Gauntlet™.  The game felt very linear and more Legends/Legacy then the arcade versions.

To the point regarding Legends and/or Legacys I felt Gauntlet™ drew more from these mondern versions than its predecessors.  Concepts of character progression, item shops, boss battles, quotes such as 'needs food badly' and many others pull from the days of Legends and/or Legacy.  Which to me as a individual playing the game I think is a good thing that they didn't try to keep the pure rustic feel of the past in Gauntlet™.  For these above reasons I feel Gauntlet™ feels more like Legends and/or Legacy than the original arcade boot.

reviewText:
Never was the biggest fan of Gauntlet, but played my fair share of Gauntlet II on the Gameboy and plenty of Tengen Gauntlet on the Mega Drive. That being said, I don't feel like this reimagining of Gauntlet does a good job at being a good Gauntlet-game or a very exciting arcade-game.

The reasons for this assessment are manyfold. My main gripe is that they kind of broke the classic Gauntlet formula in a poor attempt at modernizing the game to appeal to 2014 audiences. What do I mean by that? Well, new Gauntlet SHOULD have been a twinstick-shooter with a melee component - instead we get a rather dull hack'n'slay were fifty percent of the cast suffer from not having their ranged attacks anymore. In fact, only the Elf plays anything like the Gauntlet I remember - the wizard, being all Magicka-like, is actually completely screwed and way too fiddly for my taste. Melee classes are all about kiting hordes and then killing a whole bunch in one fell swoop. The game kinda sits between two chairs, they wanted to make the characters more diverse than they were before - but in doing so they broke the subtle balancing of the original. At the same time, unfortunately, combat isn't quite as awesome as say something like Sacred 3 or Iron Fisticle, two games which kind of do the Gauntlet-thing but are so much more exciting and really make you feel powerful. Gauntlet just doesn't have much impact and seems kinda wimpy.

Next up; the stages are extremely boring. The original Gauntlet had like a hundred different mazes, that were so much more interesting than the entirety of this reboot. You know, there were teleporter pads, hidden walls, warpzones and all kinds of other stuff along some very interesting and sometimes even quite clever layouts. Some of the labyrinths had such striking layouts that you would remember them - in the 2014 reboot everything blurs together. New Gauntlet is mostly letting you repeat the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over again. Each of the three worlds" is split into 3x3 segments that are basically: Stage I: dungeon crawling
recommended: darkness or fireballs and Stage III: arena-battles. The forth segment is usually an uninspired boss fight. Which are not very exciting in multiplayer and downright tedious in single player. Reminding me more about the average MMO than proper Arcade-stuff.\n\nThe problem is that the very few elements that are in the game (monster spawners
hoursPlayed: locked doors) are so basic that they get old incredibly fast. And new Gauntlet has no idea how to mix it up and keep you interested for longer periods of time (as a reminder: spawners in the old game would be tents or piles of bones

reviewText:
I'm sorry but I am actually disappointed at this game. I just completed the game on normal and I can't say I want to play it again. The 4 classes are somewhat similar to Legends and Dark Legacy, but the Wizard was way different than the other classes having 9 total spells. The other classes aren't that interesting in comparison. I thought the level design was too simple; it lacked the charm and puzzle solving like in Dark Legacy: hidden invisible walls, switches, boss weapons, mini bosses, cool itmes, gems, etc.

Really though, there are a list of things I didn't like in this game. I didn't grow up with the 1985 version, I grew up with Legends and Dark Legacy; games of which had a decent hack and slash system with a good balance of magic and puzzles.

Pros:
Good graphics
Funny as hell
Multiplayer was simple and straight forward

Cons:
Lack of class design between the characters
Simplistic level design
Relics are expensive and can't be used enough
Armor doesn't do anything, cosmetic
SHORT ~ 5 hours!
Lack of items and elements from previous generation
Enemies were boring after about an hour
The Elf couldn't auto attack the generators!!!
The story was boring and anticlimatic
Couldn't select the same class in multiplayer and couldn't customize much
Masteries didn't change the game much, couldn't even view them in game

3/10

I was really hoping for more in this game. It easily could have been $50 with more content, customization, and level design. I miss Dark Legacy so much, I expected more from this.

reviewText:
Super disapointing game. And somehow inferior to its previous versions. The game is very short to play through and after that it's just a boring, pointless grind that only rewards you with achievements and vanity gear that you can't really see in game that well anyway.

Pros
+ Can be fun to play (for a few hours anyway) with a group of friends
+Some humorous aspects
+The graphics are decent

Cons
-Not fun to play alone.
-Not fun in random groups (people can and will screw you over).
-You share a screen with your whole group (which causes multiple issues)
-Not possible to join a game in progress. If you get dc'd you cant rejoin your friends and they will have to finish without you.
-Not much variation in difficulties. Except Unfair which is just stupid.
-Most characters have only a couple attacks. Except the wizard which is a weird pain to switch between his spells on the keyboard.
-Nothing good to spend your gold on. The gear is all vanity items which is so bad because it doesn't look that special.
-You can beat this game in about 5-6 hours and then wish you hadn't bought the game.
-Weird bugs where I would randomly fall through the floor or just spontaneously die with no enemies around.
-The story is really basic and only really applies to the start and end of the game. All the middle bosses have no meaning. And then of course the ending was predictable and the last boss was easy. To reward you for finishing the game you get to see a slideshow of 3 paintings.

Its a very short simple game and it isn't worth more than $5. I wouldn't recommend paying anything more than that for it.

reviewText:
I have played my fair share of Gauntlet games in my day. Originally in the arcades, every death meant I had to pump more quarters into the machine. Now, with the series hitting multiple consoles spanning different generations, Gauntlet is back after a rather long hiatus. Is it back to the feelings we all know and love, or was that really just me looking back with rose-tinted glasses? After playing this, I may be going with the latter.

In a very arcadey fashion, Gauntlet puts players in the role of one of four classes. In a top-down view, they will hack and slash (or shoot arrows and fireballs depending on the class) at hoards of enemies while they try to make it through the dungeons while gathering as much gold as they can. Don’t forget getting chased by death himself in some of the more frantic levels.

Progression is done not through leveling up, but through masteries. There are even death masteries that will allow characters to not take as much damage from certain traps if they die enough from them. Basically, doing normal stuff throughout the game will allow players to get better at that certain skill. It’s not groundbreaking in any way, but it at least let me improve my characters.

The classic classes are all back, and each plays very differently from one another. The Warrior is a brutal melee fighter, the Valkyrie utilizes her shield to both block and attack from afar, the Elf uses bows and bombs and the Wizard combines elements to fire off magical attacks. Each has their own play style and really changes up how the player will handle situations, but in the end, most of it is pretty mindless.

The standout here is the co-op play. Online multiplayer with three other people was a frantic, hack n slash mess, but in a good way. Since it didn’t take much thought to play, we ended up have a fun time just hacking away at enemies while talking. Also, fighting for the crown when someone would get hit quickly became the meta-game of it all, even though the crown does nothing except increase points at the end of the level.

The story is minimal at best, but the voice acting that is there, along with the comedic overtones are well done and even made me laugh a few times. Sure, there is no “Sexy pants!” being screamed like in Sacred 3, but the dialog that is there never takes itself seriously and gives off a bit of charm that I enjoyed.

Gauntlet isn’t much of a thinking man’s game. Find a class you like and have at it. The Wizard will be the one most people avoid, but even then, with a few other buddies along for the ride, it can be a rather fun time. Single player can get a bit more monotonous, but it is the same for the multiplayer; just having some others to share in the mindless action helps out a lot.

For $20, players get a rather fun game. Yeah, I still feel more love for the older versions of the game, but I think that’s just the nostalgia in me. Even in single player, I didn’t mind taking on the hoards of enemies with my shield throwing Valkyrie. Jumping online is where the game gets hectic, but way more fun, and the tongue-in-cheek nature of the dialog and story offer up a few laughs at times. I would say pick it up, but if you do, try to at least convince one or two friends to pick it up with you. You’ll all have a more enjoyable time together.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
If you've played past Gauntlet games you'll come to realize shortly after starting the tutorial stage that this is almost  NOTHING  like past games of the series.

The only things that I found similar are:
4 Player Co-Op
The announcer exclaims things like. Your health is getting low!"
Oh you shot the food? It's gone now.
Secret passages
RUN FROM DEATH
Things missing from past Gauntlet games:
Persistant Stats. The armor from the shop? Yeah it's cosmetic.
Buying benificial shop items. Besides the stat boosts which is obviously gone. You also can't buy magic potions
recommended:
that little Phoenix that would follow you around and add projectiles on top of your own attacks. Yeah none of that exists. You can only buy 'relics' now.
No shield button. That's gone too. One class has a shield. The others have different abilities like charge or a dodge roll. Wizard doesn't have any of those. But he does have a spell shield he can cast that breaks after a short duration.
Things that are largely different from past Gauntlet games:
Characters have a skill that goes on cooldown and a couple benificial abilities instead of a basic attack that would automatically choose a ranged or melee attack.
Magic potions don't damage things on the screen. Now they're used to power 'relic' items you purchase with gold from the shop. Not necessarily as great or had the same powerful impact as dropping a lightning potion on the screen and frying things to a crisp.

TL;DR
If you have never played a Gauntlet game. You might actually find this game is eh

- Food and potion system is stupid, especially because you can destroy them with abilities if you do so before you pick them up
- Lacks character progress
- stages and enemies are very similar to Diablo 2, lacking personality
- The Wizard class is a copy of Invoker from Dota2 or Magicka

reviewText:
I like this game a lot, its very beautifull and fun to play, but... There is a lot of things which making you feel that something is quite wrong. First of all, cooperation: there is just no way to speak with others (no chat), not even an emotes or basic movement directions for party — you have to gues what others have on their mind. It could be played solo, but this way its pretty booring and super hard. So you have to eather use real life friends or skype to talk with people, which isnt really good. When you enter the lobby... Well, there is no lobby lol. You simply pick desired difficulty among 4 (where the first one is actually hard and the last one is 'bloody hell, damn it, get away from me!!!'). And if you want to beat some special level among 12, at current exact moment — you cant do it, cus there is no way to predict which one party leader will choose to play (but you can create ye own game and wait few hours for people to connect to you). Also this influences other side of game — you can pick two of many special abbilities, which are good on some levels and bad on other and there is no way to understand what to take with you since you have no idea where gonna go.

Now a bit about classes balance. Warrior is beyond patheticness. Seriously, this guy is slow, his dodge ability requires charge and have direction restrictions. Autoattacks damage is very low, so he needs 3-4 of those to wipe one single smallest enemy. He isnt able to do anything cus mostly have to fight in melee combat with only one aoe damage skill. And some monsters can two shot you. The other problem — you must click mouse button once to execute each swing of your weapon, which is just lame and requires button mashing your mouse. While mage have 7 active AoE spells, 2 crowd controlls and mostly one shots any monster. Yes mage also can simply push and hold attack button to land spells non stop.

Now a bit more about coop. There is almost no way to get fun of your team, cus when you destroy their food, deal damage to them by enviroment or corner (preventing any movement) — this leads to their funny death, but also will make others members to die, cus monsters dont care about your dumb fun jokes, they simply kill you. And when everyone dies, you will have to replay SAME level WITHOUT any random generation. Dont take me wrong — game is nice, there is lots of secret areas, nice graphics, many hard situations to overgo, but playing same area over and over and over... You cant just revive mates like in Left 4 Dead 2, nooo,  you gonna suffer. It is very interesting to play each stage for the first time, since there is special traps and logical 'mini games', but only for once.

Between levels you can spend gathered gold to buy stuff. Each class has his own treasury chest so you have to actuall play (farm a lot)with that hero, before gearing him up. Yet, that gear changes visuals only, and getting 2 active skills pretty easy task, so we can say: there is no shop at all and no progression. Now about achievements — all heroes have the same types of them, so if you gonna play some hero for a long time, you will get lots of nice bonuses, but have to repeat it it for every one else. Anyway, they wount change game flow even a bit, they exist just to exist.

Right now i would not recomend it for solo players or those who seek fun with random people. It also lags a bit on lava levels even on minimum settings, so you have to get better pc then my'n (iCore5 3000Hz, 4gb ram, 2gb video gts 640, windows 7).

Again — this is good game and i LIKE it, but right now its not ready to take a place in our heart. Have to wait and see what ddevs gonna change.

reviewText: Gauntlet and Gauntlet legends were some of my fav games as a child much like many of the other players on here. The community in gauntlet is great, the game is pretty fun and can be played local, online and local/online mixed co-op which gives it a thumbs up from me, and the endless mode is great fun. It's ultimately the greatest nostalgia party game in my opinion for 20-40 year olds (even older or younger it doesn't discriminate). I remommend getting a party of your friends who enjoyed it as children with you and doing a local co-op game together for the best experience.\nI do have some cons however, nothing that can really be helped though. The Story mode is fun however not incredibly replayable and quite short, the game is quite buggy and wb will not be updating the game and/or making a sequel ever as production has finished according to forums I have been on regarding it. Add to this playing by yourself is actually terrible for some strange reason (perhaps the loneliness) I would reccomend 2-4 players.\nDespite this I have had an enjoyable time playing and would rate the game an 8.5 out of 10. I have played many revamps of gauntlet and this is gauntlet how I most fondly remember it. Thanks WB

reviewText:
There's something wrong with this game - and I'm still not sure what it is.

Is it well-balanced, fun? Yep
Now that's out of the way - there's a few very odd design decisions.

In putting in the ubiquitous levelling up, story, background and achievements, they've missed something of the original and the sequels - its open world" feel. All of the dungeons are built to a very specific standard and focus you tightly down the next "surprise". Even if that's not explained to you what the surprise is - three times I had to return to the hub purely because I'd not done what the designer expected me to.

It feels very much like a 2010 game in that all of your choices are made for you and drilled in from the start. There's no discovery curve as sort
date: just a line of achievements that act as little red ticks from the teacher.\n\nSaying that
recommended: it's still fun - all of the characters have a different style
hoursPlayed: the key sound is there - but it's definitely lost some of its charm. DEATH is now an enviromental hazard
voteText:
Ghosts are now missiles of a sort; and it's set around Boss Monsters rather than Hordes - like every other game.

7/10 - Treading the same old path rather than creating a new style.

minus another point until they fix issues like swapping characters between games
helpfulPercent: swapping screen size and swapping keyboard controls. It will get a recommended when that's fixed."

reviewText:
I've played the Gauntlet games since I had an NES as a kid.  Between the original and Gauntlet: Dark Legacy I put many many cherished hours into these games.  They were difficult and intricate.  The one thing they lacked was a significant difference between the characters.  This game has that--which I like--I never understood why every character had ranged attacks in previous installments.  That's all it has over the older Gauntlets.  The warrior is purely melee (and the worst class), the Valkyre is primarily melee with limited ranged attacks (and is the second worst class), and the wizard and archer are ranged powerhouses.
It took just a few hours to beat the game solo on normal difficulty.
There's no real leveling system, just gold to be spent on either gear (whose availability is dependant on what levels you've beaten on what difficulty, plus you have to pay for them) or Relics (which are not unique to your character).
It's kind of fun, and I'm still waiting for my friends to install their copies so I can try three or four player mode, but it's not worth the price tag of $15 or $20.

reviewText:
TLDR: Highly recommended, good fun in single player or multiplayer and ok for people who get motion sick from fps or moba style games.

If you're thinking of getting this game, first thing I suggest you do is look at some gameplay on youtube. I have an indepth overview and review with gameplay here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qQe6N-Bjjfo (hour long) and Zerohill has an awesome 20 video playlist you can see here https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLEg-yDRmLEZ1F0zYiE14ciggS71YnssXX

The aim of the game

Morak the magician created the gauntlet for power & got trapped inside. Your job is to fight through hordes or mummies, walking dead, undead, skeletons, grunts, orcs, etc., to bring him 3 shards of a sword so he can escape the gauntlet. In return he promises riches & power.

The Characters, their weapons & attacking skills

Thor (Warrior): Carries a battle axe and does large sweeping slashes which lay waste to the enemy. Can also do a double handed vertical chop (think log splitting). And when in a bind, a spinning attack which decimates the hordes around him. And can do a charge to barge the enemy out of the way.

Thyra (Valkyrie): Has a Shield, sword and speer. For close quarter combat she slashes with her sword. When the enemies are nearby she can throw her shield (Capt America style) and take out groups or lines of enemies. And she has a speer thrust which can also take out a line of enemy fast, as well as get her out of a swarming group. She also has a shield block which reflects projectiles back at the enemy who threw them at her and protects her from the slashes of sharp fingernailed attackers. She can move while she has the shield up, although slower.

Questor (Elf): He has a bow and arrow and an elf bomb which he can drop on the ground or attach to his snipe arrows. His normal arrows are rapid fire and short range. His snipe shot is longer range and has more power but isn't as rapid. Use the snipe/bomb arrow to shoot into a Summoning stone from afar - or single enemy troop and the troops around will blow up. His elf bomb can also be dropped into the middle of a horde to blow them up. For quick escapes he has a tumble roll.

Merlin (Wizard): He has 9 basic spells to choose from... Close quarter ice (freezes enemy in place), Ice beam (think laser beam) and Ice lob bomb (which creates a frozen circle which slows down the enemy. Fire balls (not as rapid as elf arrows but do more damage), fire lob bomb and can move quickly as a couple of snaking fireball things. Chain lightening, a force blast which knocks over the enemy and a force shield he and others can stand in.

Lillith (Necromancer): An add on character which can be purchased seperately to the game itself, her stock standard weapons are a small skeleton which rises to swipe the enemy a distance from her and a large skeleton with a sledge hammer that bashes down on groups of enemy or large items. As she takes out an enemy she gains some of their Soul Energy which she can use to raise a small group of fighters to help her.

Weapon Abilities

Each character can change their main weapon to give it slightly different abilities. E.g. choose a different bow and the elf's bomb becomes a keep enemy in place" bomb and allows you to then kill them while they stand still. His normal arrows are not changed when this bow is used. The warrior can change his axe so that the double handed log splitting chop wipes out all the enemies around him in one blow. Valkyrie and Wiz also have different abilities.

Talismans

These change what happens when a potion is used. At the beginning the use of a potion simply blows it up and damages anything in the blast zone. Later they can be changed E.g. One use for the Valkyries becomes creating 3 valks to fight for her. Each character's Taslisman change is different.

Relics

Theses are items you can buy in the game (with gold earned in the game) to enhance your character's abilties. Some enable you to move faster
date:
others create a whirlwind around you. One creates illusions of your character which can attack the enemy along side you.

Q&A - Answering unasked questions and bad review claims

Bad review claim: The game lacks content.

My take: Without any elaboration in what way it lacks content
recommended: the statement isn't helpful and says more about the reviewer than the game. The game has 30 missions in Campaign mode
hoursPlayed: which can be played on Easy
voteText: Normal or Hard
helpfulPercent: so it is kind of like 90 different missions. Each can be played with one of four main characters for a total possible 360 possible different mission experiences. Add to this the Endless option which has you go through an endless number of floors which are made up on the fly - and can be done solo or with others. The top players have reached floor 8
votesHelpful:
192!!! And then there is the Colleseum which pits you against waves of beasties in a one room arena - 6 waves completes the mission and each day there is a new mission with different gameplay in a new arena. I wouldn't call that "lack of content".

Bad review claim: Only 6 to 8 hrs of game play.

My take: At the time of this review I have over 140 hrs of game time. I only have 30 of 46 achievements
votesTotal: have not completed the campaign fully by myself in Normal or Hard mode in any single character. Have only managed to get to floor 79 in Endless mode with a team of people (only managed floor 8 by myself as elf) and have completed only two missions in the Colesseum. Makes me wonder if those who think "only 6 to 8 hours" actually tried or just rode along in easy mode multiplayer until the campaign was done and then called it quits
votesFunny: or just found the game too hard. Because with all the achievements
commentsCount: character upgrades and missions
column16:
there is no way it can all be done in only 6 to 8 hours.

Bad review claim: Boring.

Again
column17: without elaboration the statement is meaninless. Boring compared to what? Would they find the classic games like Space Invaders or Pacman or Donkey Kong boring? Millions of people around the globe used to go out of their way to play those games in "pinball parlors". There is so much which can be done in this game
column18: any claim it is boring
column19: says more about the reviewer than the game itself.\n\nI have a sneaky feeling the "lacks content"
column20: "only a few hours game play" and "boring" reviewers are most likely young kids. Maybe it's boring because their mates won't play with them
column21: because maybe their mates think fps is the shiznits and everything else is boring? And I can see "kids" completing a room in easy mode and considerig it "done" without going back there ever in any other character or harder mode. Or the game is too hard for them so instead of admitting they find it too hard
column22: blame the game for lack of content
column23: not long in hours or boring.\n\nFact is
column24: the graphics are good
column25: the game play is progressively harder (something all good games have in common)
column26: it can be played in a mode that suits your skill level and is great for people who suffer video game motion sickness. It can be played on your own whenever you want to spend a few minutes playing
column27: or played with friends or even strangers and can be played in a variety of characters.\n\nYou do not Need to play it in multiplayer. You can play it by yourself in single player mode without interacting with the server and other players. Most of my gameplay is like this as I use the time to get better with the various characters (so I'll be a good asset to any multiplayer team I join) and when I don't have the time to complete the campaign or whatnot with others and want to spend 15 or 30 minutes playing
column28: or just don't feel like playing with others. Playing solo means you can go at your own pace and fully explore each mission in the campaign.\n\nSometimes

reviewText:
This doesn't even FEEL like Gauntlet. They changed way too much and it has this Torchlight II rip off kind of vibe. Torchlight II is actually way better compared to this. The voiceovers are HORRIBLE. The style is just strange. Not what I was expecting at all!! I feel like it was a waste of my money. Wasn't worth the price at all! It's barely worth $1 in my eyes because it's just not anything like old school Gauntlet. Someone really allowed Gauntlet to be butchered!
They need to look back at like Gauntlet Dark Legacy and bring something like that back with a bit of a more modern twist if they'd like and online co-op compatibilities with that. Not this garbage.
Within the first few minutes I found out that they basically rigged it where you need others so you can get through it or so you can destroy everything that is breakable OR you have to repeat the same level over and over and over and over and rely on gold.
They could have done SOOOO much with this!!!
1) Death should be the original death that was scared away with potions and took away EXP and health.. Not this instant death crap.
2) Potions should be useable right away as welllll magic potions!
3) Loot should only be visible to the player in front of the screen so there isn't any fighting between actual people.
4) There should be an in game chat for it. I've heard plenty of people complaining about this and I haven't found out for myself yet but I don't think I will anyways.
5) The coins thing to revive yourself is a neat idea but I think when in co-op mode other players should be able to run over and revive you no matter what even if it's just a small amount of health and when you're playing alone it should more of the coin based thing or else each person should have their own coins but NOOO! They have to share coins to revive... Lame.
6) They should have gotten better voice actors and actresses!!!
7) The weapons.. Oh come on... With hoards. I miss the old style Gauntlet where they threw the weapons! Now they don't throw the weapons! So sad!
8) They should have the level up system like Gauntlet Dark Legacy where the outfit changed as you got stronger and you got a little ally to help out once you reached like lvl 50 or whatever it was! Not this buy your gear bs. It's not even worth it.
9) There should be more customization to the characters!!!!! The woman looks like a darn tank who had her eye shoveled out. -.-
Anddd there's a whole lot more I could go on about but I figure this is enough for one review...
I am not pleased. Severely disappointed!!!!
I hope my friends don't waste their money.

reviewText:
All of us growing up in the golden age of standup arcade games remember the beast of a machine Gauntlet was. 4 player coop was unheard of at the time and boy did we like it. So this new rendition of Gauntlet takes that basic formula and steps it up a notch by giving each hero some new skills that gives it a much more modern hack 'n slash feel. And it works. It manages to hold a nostalgic presence while still feeling refreshingly new. They've added some character level ups to keep it interesting and there is even a difficulty setting if you feel like adding a little more challenge.

The biggest shortcoming with Gauntlet is the disproportionate skill set when it comes to the Wizard. He has way too many abilities and other cool effects than anyone else, so playing anyone else feels kind of under whelming. The other significant blemish is its short campaign length. The first playthrough is fun and exciting, but it quickly loses luster on subsequent playthroughs.

The new Gauntlet is indeed fun and best experienced in a full 4-player cooperative, but the game eventually gets stale due to it's short levels and repetitive game play--kind of like the original.

reviewText:
It's not just marketing talk when they say this Gauntlet is a completely new experience. I've put hundreds of hours into Gauntlet Legends on the N64, and quite a few into Dark Legacy on the gamecube. I had expectations going into this game.

This is a very different game.

Is it fun? Yes. It's a good game, and it's fun. We'll get that out of the way first. However, it's nothing like classic Gauntlet games. Each of the classes play very differently; they're not just different allocations of stats. As a matter of fact, there really is no notion of stats" in this game: there's no leveling
date: no character progression.\n\nThe only difference in a start-game and end-game character is what gear you have equipped - most of which is only for aesthetic purposes. You have 3 important pieces of gear: Your weapon
recommended: an accessory that changes what your potions do
hoursPlayed: and a relic that gives you an extra cooldown-based ability. The only mechanical difference in your weapons is what your special ability does (in the case of the wizard it seems like ability sets rather than a single ability). More expensive weapons don't mean more damage
voteText: more range
helpfulPercent: or anything like that.\n\nLevels in this game vary widely in how long they take. Some only take a couple minutes. Others take up to 10. There also aren't too many levels in the game
votesHelpful: and there are only 3 bosses
votesTotal: but all the bosses have very different mechanics.\n\nThe bottom line is that it's a short but sweet game. I have trouble finishing 4 player co-op games with friends due to conflicting schedules and waning interests
votesFunny: but we had no problem sticking this one out. You can easily get through it your first time in 3 to 6 hours."

reviewText: I had never played any of the Gauntlet series in the past but my friend was a BIG TIME fan of the series and convinced me to buy this game on release. We started playing and at first nostalgia struck for my friend, but after that it just became the same thing over and over again. To start we ended up beating the entire game on hard difficulty in only a few hours. Every level was pretty much the same design with the same type of monsters with just graphical differences. It was almost like they imported the same monsters same soul stones and just made them look different. The bosses on the other hands were sometimes buggy and not very challenging at all. We found that the first boss we fought was significantly harder than the last one. So far you would think this is a decent game with a few repetetive things that might be a little too easy. But that's not the worst of it. After you build up all yours coins you can buy a few relics" that really don't do much to help you and usually you forget all about them anyways
date:
but the worst part is that you can spend all your hard earned coins on "Armor and weapons" WHICH ARE PURELY COSMETIC! If they actually had a bonus or made you better. With all that said let's go over the pros and cons once again.

CONS-
Way too easy unless you're playing the hardest difficulty
Found some graphical bugs that made me have to restart mid-game
Hardly any puzzles non of which are challenging
Nothing of value to spend your coins on making collecting them kind of pointless
Lazy level design with more of the same things you've already seen with a graphical revamp

PROS-
A decent co-op experince even if it's too easy
Pretty good graphics all around
Very Diverse characters and abilities

- CONCLUSION
I wouldn't recommend buying this game because it does not nearly live up to the hype
recommended: but if you are a hardcore Gauntlent fan and really must have it I'd say wait for it to go on sale."

reviewText:
Worst thing about this game - it reminded me that I played the original on the Atari in the late 80s and I feel OLD. If you enjoyed any of the Gauntlet series you should enjoy this. It stays pretty true to the original concept, whilst bringing enough new things and remastered graphics to make it seem worth another remake.

If you know nothing of the series (seriously, why?) it's a rampaging dungeon crawler with the very simple aim of kill all the things, collect all the golds and ramp up high scores which obviously improves your e-peen.

If you're the competitive sort, the leaderboards (both global and friend-based) will add a ton of replayability, and the masteries system gives incentive to play each of the 4 heroes all of which do actually play surprisingly differently.

Some downsides worth noting are that keys aren't currently rebindable (just a simple choice between keyboard or gamepad), and no chat at all. Even just chat in the lobby would be useful when finding random groups on higher difficulties so you can discuss who is prioritizing taking food, or who might shoot it because they've unlocked the masteries etc.

As with any co-op game you're going to get the best out of this if you have actual friends and a voice chat. If you have no friends like me (sadface), it's a bit RNG whether you get people who are looking to progress in a game, people who are just looking to have fun and work on masteries, or those just out to troll you.

I've still been having a lot of fun playing this single player but I can imagine getting a group of friends together on skype and hitting this up would be awesome.

Devoted Gauntlet: Legends fans; walk away."

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is for the Slayer Edition.

+++ Polished, consistent experience
+++ Great gameplay difference between the four characters

--- Uninspired art direction
--- Repetitive slog with little variance between the proposed challenges
--- Short and forgettable campaign, coupled with an overly drawn-out Endless Mode
--- Multiplayer gameplay friendly to griefing

Gauntlet attempts the impossible task of recapturing the allure of a long bygone era when coin-op arcades were king.  For the exercise, although it did produce a fairly solid foundation, fact remains that the project is doomed to failure: the classic Gauntlet game just cannot exist in today's world without profound changes.  In keeping its design philosophy close to the now thirty year-old original, Gauntlet by its own definition offers but little replay value.  A paper-thin story is laid on top of enough artifices to make it all seem like a modern game, but the facade quickly shatters away, and the game's true nature is revealed within minutes: room after room of same-y monsters and spawners, lost in a maze with little personality of its own.

Gauntlet feels a lot like a proof of concept, more than a genuine full-fledged game, and though Slayer Edition vastly improved on the first version, there is still a lot of work to be done for this to consider itself in any fashion a modern game adapted to today's world.  Right now, for the price, there are much more engrossing games in the same genre out there, with a lot more content and replay value.

reviewText:
I picked up the 2014 version of Gauntlet. I've given the game 15 hours so far since its release so I believe I can make an honest assessment of game from both the nostalgic (I put at least $300 into the original arcade version) and modern game design and playing perspectives. Keep in mind I play this with a keyboard and mouse (Razer Naga).

The Good

1. The game play and design are polished with a few exceptions. The game feels like Gauntlet in 2014 and that is a good thing. The same run around, find keys, open doors, get potions, and the characters and narrator are all there from the original. What has changed is the fun factor and a much shorter game. The characters do more, they are flashier and more unique, and they feel solid when played. Questor the Elf definitely has the easiest playstyle, followed by Thyra the Valkyrie, Thor the Warrior, and finally Merlin the Wizard who is definitely the hardest to play.

2. I found myself enjoying Thyra for the best balance of defense and offense. Thyra has great movement, can block any attack (yes any, even the end boss), and has a great offense as well. I suggest for starting players if you want to get into the fray, choose Thyra first.

3. The mastery levels are nice touch and I really like how they build your character up. You have to choose before you go in whether you are going for no deaths or to dying a million times on purpose.

4. $20 is about the perfect price for the game. I can honestly say I am glad I bought it.

The (Somewhat) Bad

1. Numerous bugs still exist in the game (crashes at times, sound cuts out, visual bugs). Luckily these aren't game-breaking.

2. The camera tries hard to be there for you but currently it leads to more deaths than to give you a clear view of the game. In reality I wish each player had their own screen to look at (e.g. Diablo 3) versus the 3/4-view that traps players.

3. Not being able to check your mastery progression at any time in the game is very annoying. A key to do this needs to be added.

4. Merlin plays too much like Magicka (another Arrowhead product). I programmed my Razer Naga to switch between the nine spells he has and it then became much easier to play. My guess is a lot of other people are going to do the same thing.

5. Cosmetic items are essentially worthless. I'd rather see that you have to buy new gear with better attributes after finishing a difficulty to do better in the harder difficulties than have just a look that nobody cares about.

6. Mastery progression is way too high of a curve at times - it's a ploy for replay value. I do not want to go from 2,000 to 8,000 just for 5% more of an attribute.

7. The game is too short. Normal is completed within 5 hours with a halfway decent team of players. Hopefully Arrowhead now that they have our money have a plan for future content.

8. You are forced into being only one of the four characters. While this mimics the original arcade, in this day and age I shouldn't be forced to play Merlin if I don't want to. Again, this needs to be changed to allow multiple people to live out their Legolas dreams if they wish.

The Ugly

1. The game has no way to chat with other players so you spend a lot of your time in public games using the emotes to try and cajole other players to go the way they need to go, or for you to move due to the camera getting you stuck.

2. The world leader-board was hacked within one hour of release. Currently there are players hacking to over 1.9 trillion points in single player mode. Arrowhead has yet as of this review to respond to a plan to either secure the boards or (as I've suggested on the Steam forums) remove them entirely until they have a way to fix them.

Conclusion

If you are looking for a game that can help you pass some time and is casual, then Gauntlet is definitely the kind of game to lead to a night of fun. If you are looking for something more robust and long-term then this is not the game you are looking for; I would suggest another Action RPG such as Path of Exile or Diablo 3.

reviewText: I load up gauntlet, expecting the fun and exciting adventure I had when my brother and I played on the nintendo 64 and Playstation 2. I wanted the exciting inventory items, the new powers and skills that came with levelling up, magical artifacts, powers, shopping and super attacks. Instead I got a slighlty upgraded version of the original nintendo. It...was fun at first, but it got so boring, so repetitive. The tiny character models, the uninspired levels, the boring enemies, bosses that left no real feeling of accomplishment and the store" carries objects that cost a fortune to buy and barely offer anything to modify or alter gameplay or your character.\nIf you own gauntlet on the nintendo 64 or on the playstation then just stick to that and pass this one over. It is a retro game
date: but you lose alot when you strip away all the updates and ideas that came with the incredibly addictive modern gauntlet games.\nLet this game sit with gauntlet seven sorrows as it is just as dull and bland."

reviewText: Meh. Having learnt to like it, they've broken it. I enjoyed it in the 1.x version they produced as it was as a casual, dippable pick-it-up-when-you-felt-like-it game, which bore some similarity to Gauntlet (unlike some of the other games with that name). Now they've changed the levels and the menus so it's not the same game. So, the original arcade-ish experience of learning levels and gaining bonuses to improve has now been... discarded by the developers. It also feels clunkier with (more original-Gaunlet-like) scrolling that's restricted to rooms. And what will they do to it next. So, can't recommend.

reviewText:
Gauntlet looks like an amazing arpg at first, but it happens to be extremely repetitive.
There are only 3 different environments, no other weapons, no real inventory and the kind of maps you are exploring are always the same for every cave. This is what killed the game for me.

The graphics are nice and the game feels good, but it is very short lasting. For me it was kind of fun for about 2 hours, then it became annoying.

Buy it only if you really love simplistic arpgs and arcade games and if it is on a heavy discount!

reviewText:
Definitely a faithful representation of the original, and even better. One of the best top-down action games I have ever played. All of the classes are fun to play, especially the wizard. The way you double tap two-button combinations on the controller (XX, YB, etc.) is really smart and is the only real way you could possibly get to each spell quick enough while fighting, because you do need to be able to switch to the right spells at the right time to survive, especially on unfair mode. However it can still get confusing trying to navigate all of his spells (9 total) while being swarmed in combat, especially in unfair mode. One thing that I dislike is that bosses themselves serve no challenge. The difficulty from boss fights comes from being swarmed by other enemies while fighting the bosses. The sounds and music are very memorable, the graphics and art direction are superb, and the effects are also very well done. Probably the only complaint I have is that sometimes in 4 player games there is so much ♥♥♥♥ going on at once that it is very easy to get lost in the action or take hits when you otherwise would not have. Multiplayer is a blast and is one of the most fun games to play online. The more people there are, the harder the difficulty is. So in unfair mode with 4 players get ready for some pain.

Also, the fact that beating tougher levels on hard/unfair unlocks new gear for looks, not stats, is a joke. It's a top-down game, nobody is going to notice but you. There should be more purposeful rewards for playing through the campaign more than once. Or at least make the gear look better.

I got this when it first came out on Nuuvem (Steam is blocking Nuu vem, are you ♥♥♥♥ing serious) for $13.50 and that was a steal. It has plenty of content to justify its $20 price tag, but don't expect it to be any longer than the average length of a $20 game. If anything, I cannot wait for its inevitable expansions. I mean I hope.

8/10 after 50+ hours it is getting extremely repetitive. It needs a dlc badly.

reviewText:
Gauntlet is a game worth devoting yourself into for at least a 100h. There is so much more skill and variety than meets the eye. It's one of those games that is easy to get into, but at the same time hard to master. Gauntlet also has great replay value with several weapons on each class, several campaign difficulties and an endless mode. It's a game that is largely based on co-op, but at the same time a game in which there is a huge difference bettween a skilled player and a newbie. Meaning, this is a great co-op game, but also a challeging while not frustraring, at least for the most part, single player game.

If you're into games that have a lot of replay value, collectibles, take skill and have a rather ''existant'' community, then by all means buy gauntlet.

All that aside, it's also a fun game to just mess around in with a few buddies on a lazy weekend.

As a final note, this review is not say that gauntlet is a perfect game. It has its cons, bugs and there are things in the game which may seem ''slightly overpowered'' to newer players and some veterans alike. But when you look past all the non-sense some people claim about class balance issues, there lies a game worth investing time into.

Tl;Dr +1

reviewText:
Waaay too grindy without nearly enough variety in the levels. The rooms all seem super flat wtihout any variety in height. I remember classic gauntlet games had waterfalls, sprawling valleys, immense wooden towers, human slaughterhouses, cryptic collectables, several diverse bosses, familiars, the circus of the damned, hell, graveyards, plains saturated in green vomitous zepplin filth, caves, cooperative attacks, the list goes on and on.

All that's left is *kill 1000 enemies and you'll do five percent more damage* bonuses that rehash the gameplay as poorly as killing floor, alongside what feels like no variety in the dungeons.

Worst part is every level wtih death chasing you the graphics go haywire and artifacts make it impossible to see. No other game I play does that so I'm thinking it's not my video card.

reviewText:
Gauntlet is a reboot of the 1985 classic arcade game. The 1985 version was memorable for having four characters: Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf. Many people pour quarter after quarter to play this game since it was so addictive. The four characters are back with the same abilities that will remind Gauntlet veterans of what it was like back in the day.

This game offers modes in single player, multiplayer, and four player co-op. You will have to complete three floors of dungeons in each coliseum to unlock new group of floors. The dungeons are diverse enough and you can accidentally shoot foods like in the original. It does get tedious going through the same dungeons after dying and using up skull coins to get a new life. Once you run out of skull coins you will have to start from the first floor regardless of the floor you were in when you died. So, there are no save points on any floor.

Gauntlet also tries to be a little RPG by including Masteries. The Masteries represent the progression of the character you have chosen to play. Believe it or not, dying many times is considered an achievement. Other achievements include taking a lot of damage and using specific moves more than others. It looks to me like the character progression turns out not to be that important since the game is about shooting your way through the dungeons.

The gameplay is interesting when playing co-op or multiplayer. You can shoot each other by accident with friendly fire and that can cause some interesting friction between the players. The layout of the dungeons contains many cranks that you can turn to be able to advance to other parts of the dungeon. It is necessary to get used to being attacked by packs of monsters. In many cases you will have to destroy shacks that summon the monsters since destroying the shacks is the only way to keep more monsters from coming. Sometimes the sorcerers add to the challenge by regenerating the health of a shack with their staves and it will be up to you to kill the sorcerer before destroying the shack.

The controls are easy enough to understand: they are as simple as WASD and the mouse. Playing with ranged characters such as the Elf and the Wizard take more practice than playing with characters that fight in close quarters. I think Gauntlet is more fun when playing either multiplayer or co-op than single player.

The people who experience the original Gauntlet will find this reboot entertaining because of the classic characters and the diverse dungeons. However, if you are a diehard RPG fan looking for deep character customization and progression, you may not like Gauntlet as much as the Gauntlet fans. I think that it is best experienced with other players in multiplayer and co-op modes. The single player mode feels a little boring. This reboot looks better than previous iterations of Gauntlet games that were made after that 1985 original.

My Score: 7/10

reviewText:
Hmm. Where to begin....

Going into this (maybe I should've done more research) I was expecting something similar to previous gauntlet games, where you crawl through long and unique dungeons, slaying everything in your path.  While they did achieve the 'slaying everything in your path' part, everything else was really lackluster.  And I mean everything.

First, after beating the first little section in about 10 minutes, I looked around the main base and saw that there there were only 11 other sections like this.  Which meant that this game wasn't going to be a long one.

However, it was pretty fun.  In the post-section report, I saw that after playing a bunch, I could increase some traits for my abilities.  Kind of neat.  Then I saw how little they actually impacted game play.  Sad...

After racking up some gold, I went to the shopkeeping dude in the base.  I looked at his wares, to find he has some little trinkets that I could buy and upgrade. Cool! After looking through the 12 or so items, I realized that thats it.  Thats literally all that there is for character advancement.  No levelling.  Just trinkets, and grinding (mediocre at best) skill advancements through gameplay.

Frustrated, I buy some random gargoyle thing and move on.  Diving into all the rest of the sections in this act were all the same.  The first level is always just a single path you run thru and kill stuff.  The 2nd is always an arena-like area.  The 3rd is the boss.  We get to the first boss, hes pretty fun, moderately challenging, an appropriate third boss.

All the while, I'm just hoping that this game gets better.  My friend and I play through the 2nd act, get to the boss, and its laughably easy.  Seems silly.  Whatever.

Finally, we get to the 3rd act.  I've upgraded my trinkets, they're both pretty bad.  I spend all my time drudging through these dungeons, finding hoards of gold to spend it on a couple of trinkets that I end up never using anyway.

Beat the 3rd boss.  Somewhat interesting boss fight, but then it's game over.  Beat the whole thing in about 3 hours.

This game isn't worth 20 dollars.  I'd say wait until its on a super sale and pay 5 dollars.  I bought a game called hammerwatch for 5 dollars and have had more enjoyment and more content/gameplay. Sad. :(

reviewText:
This should have been a hit and full of nostalgia for me, I played the original arcade game back in high school and enjoyed later iterations both in the arcade and on consoles but this version is not very good.

To start with, why on Earth can you not use a native resolution of 1920x1080? In this day and age it's inexcusable to not let us do so. LCD monitors are not meant to be played in sizes other than native, it makes the screen slightly blurry and if you have a monitor like mine it will tell you that every time you start the game.

The lack of resolution options alone is enough to kill this game but it also has poor voice acting, the close-up models and especially the Valkyrie look terrible (one can argue that she does not need to be the 'uberbabe' she was in previous versions but at least make the close-ups look decent), the keys cannot be rebound which is another bone-headed move, and as you can see I did not play all that much but the dungeon design is limited and uninspired.

Gauntlet was one of the best coop games ever made, and the newer versions like legacy were amazing and despite the simple controls and mechanics were a lot of fun and the dungeons were well done and exciting, this game's only real positive is that at least the various abilites you can use are varied by class, although the wizard can be fiddly and he is much like playing magicka.

Unless they patch the resolution at the very least, don't waste your money on this major disappointment.

reviewText:
Looking for a fun, multiplayer arena brawler for friends?  Then move along.  There are far better ones out there.
Gauntlet was about frantically running around a maze, fighting off the oncoming hoard of enemies, and trying to seek an exit.  Gauntlet Legends was about exploring stages, over the top attacks, huge bosses, and playing as a chicken.
New Gauntlet is about walking around muddy-brown areas that all look the same, getting into one locked arena after another until you reach the end.  Occassionally you have to run from Death and his wonky hit box.  Seriously, though.. all previous Gauntlets are bright, gaudy affairs.  This one is all browns and greys.

Most egregious to me, though, is that the game can't detect my PS2 Dual Shock 2 controller.  That's not that it detects it and won't let me remap buttons, but that the game says is this a 360 controller? No? Then there is no controller".  Which is a load of crap in the modern world of PC gaming.

And while spell slinging as the Wizard can be fun
date: there's a game out there that can do it better (Magicka).  In fact
recommended: any good point I can think of about Gauntlet is done better by another game."

reviewText:
Y'know I really don't like AAA-ish titles, but this one is well done. It takes me back. They captured the old-school feel of Gauntlet very well.

They kept it simple, and the core gameplay is alot of fun. Multiplayer is obviously best (I played 3 players), but single player is also fun. I wouldn't buy it for singleplayer, though.

Pros:
+Fun hack-n-slash gameplay
+Classic classes that have very noticable differences between them
+Music is really good
+Graphics are crisp enough
+Controller support is top-notch
+Seems like alot of gameplay with several modes and daily challenges!

Cons:
-Twenty bones is expensive, but it goes on sale frequently (I got it for five, so I picked up the DLC for a buck, too)
-DLC worth is debatable - maybe play the core game first and see if its worth it for you, personally

For local co-op, this is quite fun!

เกมสนุกสำหรับคนชอบแนวนี้ แต่ละตัวละครมีสไตล์การเล่นไม่เหมือนกัน เล่นตัวอื่นก็สนุกคนละแบบ

ชุดที่ให้เปลี่ยน แค่เปลี่ยนลุคตัวละครที่เล็กเท่ามด แทบแยกไม่ออกว่าเปลี่ยนชุดแล้ว ชุดไม่มี status อะไรด้วย ใส่เท่ๆเฉยๆ

เกมนี้ไม่มีระบบ level แค่ทำ Archievement ได้ก็จะได้อัพสเตตัสบางส่วน สิ่งที่จำเป็นคือเงิน และราคาสกิลและชุดก็ราคาสูง ทำมาเพื่อให้เล่นซ้ำหลายรอบกว่าจะซื้อทุกอย่างได้ครบ

ระบบออนไลน์ร้างมาก เหมือนไม่มีคนซื้อเล่น เพราะ search ไม่เคยเจอ ใครไม่มีเพื่อนก็คิดเผื่อเรื่องเล่นคนเดียวด้วย

reviewText:
Does not feel worth the $20 price tag. It took 6 hours to beat the campaign all the way through and does not have much replayability, apart from each character playing differently. The levels and attacks are mundane and repetitive. Having played through it once, I have no motivation to play through it again.

There are some secret areas in the game, but they don't unlock special characters, levels, or bosses like in the old games. The secret areas just have more gold, health, and potions.

All-in-all, don't buy this if it isn't under $5. There's just not enough game to play through.

reviewText:
A fantastic revamp of a fantastic classic.
Gauntlet is quite possibly the most fun I have had killing skeletons, orcs, deamons and the like.

With four (five with dlc) characters to play, who all play differently, you can enjoy hours of slaying.
Or, better yet, hop in with your friends and really start harming bodies.

With the Slayer Edition, this game has gotten even better. Different abilities, new talismans, and a more interesting layout. What's not to love?

If you enjoy 'top down' games, this is a must.
If you enjoy somewhat retro advanture/hack and slash games, this is a must.
And if you have enjoyed any previous Gauntlet game, how have you not already bought this?

reviewText:
Gauntlet (Slayer edition) is a modern remake of the classic hack and slash game many people played in arcades and home systems. Besides being 3d, characters now have gear and special abilities that can be purchased with the gold you find in each dungeon. There are also boss fights and “death” makes a return as a nag character in several levels.

Multiplayer is pretty much the reason to own this game and they managed to carry forward the absolutely ruthless competition from the original. You will be sprinting to steal gold and deny food to other players all the while prioritizing your own survival as Gauntlet is more of a competitive co-op game than a friendly one. It’s kind of like playing Monopoly where all your friends end up hating each other by the end of the game.

The game itself is pretty short and can be completed on normal difficulty in less than 5 hours, leaving the only reason for playing it further to grind for gold to buy all the abilities and cosmetic items. Most useful abilities are very, very expensive which means that during a single playthrough you will be stuck only using a few of them. The dungeons are randomly generated, though, meaning there is at least some replayability to be found. I recommend waiting until the game drops back to it's sale price of around $5 to really get your money's worth.
