reviewText:
A true travesty to the original names of Gauntlet. The game is short, repetative, dull, boring and just all around not fun to play.

I beat the game in less than 5 hours and that was doing as much possible while playing through, extra 2 was from beating it again with a friend; I've always enjoyed exploring and collecting but this game severely lacked in every way.

I'm not a die-hard or a fan-boy, but this game is nothing like the originals I spent hours playing split screen with my friends.

reviewText:
My previous review for this (Not Recommended) listed it's many faults and was 59% agreed with so I can't be entirely wrong about it!!

Much of it's criticisms are addressed in the 'Slayer Update' but are they successful??

Good News
They removed the need to do 3 levels at-a-time - that was pretty-much universally hated so it's no surprise it's gone and that's a good thing.

They also reworked the progress system to be less linear - it's now easier to avoid the obvious 'junk upgrades' and you can customise your character to your preferences, sooner.

Bad News
None of that really changes the fact that the game isn't really that great and isn't really that much fun to play - or that you'll run out of content pretty quickly.

Single Player remains mostly horrid (the Elf is still the only class which feels like it was intended to be soloed)

Multiplayer remains a mixed bag because the variability of the classes is still there - you still need people playing certain classes - and playing them well - to get anywhere.  This isn't a game you can just 'have a laugh' with (ironic when it's coming from Magicka's developers!!)

They also messed around with the camera for some reason - it's 'lazy' in the way it follows you now - it's also harder to see which way to progress in the 'chased by Death' levels (and harder to make-out some secrets) - no idea why they did that, it just feels broken - maybe it IS broken?

Summary
If you player it before and didn't like it - you MIGHT like it more now - but don't expect a miracle

It remains a flawed game tho - it just lacks fun factor, lacks a hook to make you want to progress and lacks much content to progress INTO

Hey ho - top marks for trying to fix it - maybe the next game will do better again, certainly this is a better foundation.

reviewText: Between the original on Sega and this one, there hasn't been a great leap in game play development. There will be those who argue with me on this but I feel a lot more could have been done with the environment to make it a more inclusive game for the player. I'm personally not recommending this game but you may find a perks that suit you.\n\nGauntlet is a story of four brave heroes that go into dungeons searching for treasure. They undertake a great task of the gauntlet (onslaught of enemies) in order to achieve their richest of dreams. As players progress through levels, some enemies may simply be hiding behind doors or will keep spawning when obelisks appear. When these obelisks appear, they must be destroyed in order to stop enemies from spawning. There are four classes to choose from. The first is warrior (Thor) who is an up close melee personal type. He has a run charging ability (RT), very effective in close combat with his basic attack (X), heavy attack (Y) and his special (that needs to charge every time after use) attack can be triggered with (B). He has fourth bars of health and can take the most damage of any class. The Valkyrie (Thyra) class has the same controls (less brute force, more speed) but her special launches her shield at opponents. Additionally, the player can use her shield with the right stick to block attacks. Her health consists of only three bars. The wizard class (Merlin) has a vast amount of abilities to choose from (nine to be exact). By combining ice, fire and electricity the player can go nuts with a wide range of attacks. Some include ice kamehameha"
date: fireball bomb drops and a big electrical ball thing that can shock a bunch of opponents. Some spells will take some time to charge up but other spells can be used in the mean time. The archer (Questor) is able to fire multiple arrows at one time. He is also able to roll through enemies without harm and it's recharge time is a lot quicker compared to other class abilities. Questor has a charge shot available that will deal more damage as his attacks do not do a significant amount. There is also a DLC character available but I really think it should have been included in the original game. I find it ridiculous they are charging for an extra character (especially for the games price). The classes are given a decent amount of varying attacks but I find a lot more could have been done to make the player more excited to play those classes. In other words
recommended: more attack variances would have been appreciated as it would combat repetitiveness of the game. The variety of enemies is decent at best as some enemies will have you on your toes trying to defeat them. Loot in game shows up in reasonable amounts but if your low on life
hoursPlayed: it's sometimes hard to get back into the game. You'll be playing a lot more defensive (especially with more players) as health isn't a significant resource in the game. Not only that
voteText: your fighting with 3 other people to get it. There are barrels of explosives available to displace or destroy in order to defeat enemies but the game doesn't go over and above that when it comes to breakable objects. Sure you can break a vase and even break your own food. Unfortunately
helpfulPercent: no walls or rails can be broken with force. The maps themselves are alright and they really try to keep the player engaged with floor traps or jump beacons. Sooner or later though
votesHelpful:
you'll find yourself struggling to keep playing.

The graphics are decent to say the least and the sounds are alright. Players may taunt in game and use some dialogue to communicate to their fellow player to hurry up. Dialogue isn't exactly diverse but you'll hear the players pipe in once in a while. The head guy in charge of the Gauntlet will also chime in once a while with his corny jokes.

Overall
votesTotal: if you're a hardcore Gauntlet fan you may like it (or may like it for the fact you played in on Sega). I personally find this game too much of a grind and if I'm not playing with friends
votesFunny: it isn't exactly fun. Even when I do play with friends
commentsCount:
we don't often play past a level.


RATING : 6.95/10

reviewText:
FOOD IS GOOD!

Many hours of my childhood were spent in the Dungeons of Gauntlet: Legends and Gauntlet: Dark Legacy. Chock full of treasure, secrets, and endless hordes of enemies, this reboot is everything I could have hoped for in a fun co-op game! Especially with the very resonable $20 pricepoint.

The unique special abilities of each character have been well thought out and bring something useful to the party. The upgrade system for these abilities allows for more personalized customization to fit your playstyle.

If you're here for nostalgia and good co-op fun: 10/10

If you're here for stats tracking and bragging rights: Go back to Call of Duty.

reviewText: Nothing like the original game and hardly what is advertised. Gameplay consists entirely of moving from room to room, being locked in and then fighting waves of enemies before proceeding to repeat the cycle. Bosses are annoying puzzles and gimmicks. Weapons and armor are purely cosmetic. Potions are now used solely to power relics. What little 'upgrades' there are come from perks
date:
which are small bonuses awarded for grinding for hours. Which is what this game is. A mediocre grind. Relics are a waste of gold. Some don't even work properly. Armor is cosmetic. There isn't anything worth spending that hard earned gold on.

-Boring, repetitive gameplay
-Bad boss design
-Bugs that will mess with your game
-Lack of items or worthwhile character progression

The only thing this game has in common with the classic Gauntlet is the name and the four character archetypes.

reviewText:
Hours of Arcade fun for you and a group of friends. (Playing with a group makes it 10x better.)

This new iteration of gauntlet holds true to the legacy of the series, and overall is a very satisfying addition to the gauntlet family that all fans of the game can enjoy.  Character classes are unique from one another and have distinctive abilities which make cooperative play that much more engaging when a team really coordinates well.

The only slight downside I'll note, is that the game can feel rather short. With only a handful of zones, each with 5 levels a piece, a capable party can crush their way through the normal campaign in a relatively quick timeframe, with the only option for continued play being to kick the difficulty up a notch and start over again.  Still, for the price and the fun involved, I'd say it's well worth it. 7/10

reviewText:
I was pleasantly suprised by this game when I discovered it was a significant improvment on its predecessors. I enjoyed playing both the original arcade version of Gauntlet Legends and the PS 2 Gauntlet Dark Legacy.

Pros:
Fantastic and fairly well balanced multiplayer.
Each character actually has unique abilities/skills (for once) which make them better in different combat situations.
Can be challenging at times, instead of everyone blowing up everything instantly.
Fair voice acting and dialogue
Moody atmosphere as opposed to really cheesy music blaring constantly.
Secret areas require some thought and perception instead of firing weapons randomly and hoping to hit something.
Boss fights more innovative and less hit-until-dead.

Cons:
Sometimes a bit laggy, even with computers that have good specs.
Fairly short compared to Dark Legacy, but not a terribly short game overall.

All in all, I would give this game a 9.5/10 for its significant gameplay and graphical improvements while still holding true to the feeling of the original games. A solid and well-rounded game with a hint of the childhood classic we remember.

reviewText: Fans of the classic Gauntlet games rejoice. While this game isn't exactly like the older ones, it brings a really good mix with some newer elements that just make the game feel very polished. Several different characters to choose from that all feel very different, as well as a good amount of trinkets to make your gameplay unique. This game supports multiplayer with up to 4 people total, and thats definitely the best way to play. It's incredibly fun going through a dungeon with three other friends fighting over the crown which awards bonus points at the end, all while plowing through waves of enemies. Anyone who likes Gauntlet or any other type of dungeon crawler should consider picking this up for their steam library.

reviewText: I was really excited about this game when I first heard it was coming out. I finally picked it up and played for about 2 hours and was done. This is the EXACT same game that sacred 3 is. We shunned Sacred 3 for being boring and dropping no loot and the like but this game gets a pass!? I can't wait until developers stop catering to peoples nostalgia and actually make something new. You can take an old franchise and breath new life into it, look at Tomb Raider.\nThis game starts off assuming you've played the older games and has the whole  I'm not gonna tell you what this does. " mentality that plagues a lot of games lately so they can say they're not holding your hand. I remember just having a good time when I played the older ones
date: nothing was rocket science it was just good ol hack and slash. Then I played the wizard for a smash and was just like Why!? Why does his mechanics have to be so wierd and complicated!? Also I get that the co-op is the shining force of the game
recommended: but that doesn't mean people don't ever play single player. If you do play single player the game does not scale for single player it just throws huge waves at you until they can get one hit( which translates to about 3-4 hits because you get bounced around like a ping pong ball) while your trying to take down these shrines
hoursPlayed: almost mocking you and laughing because your friends were'nt around at the time.\nYour character is not very nimble either as the move I thought was supposed to atleast get you out of sticky situations has a second and a half start up and goes about six feet in front of you (I'm looking at you Valkyrie) so what's the point? I got tired of the reaper mechanic after the first time I saw it. It's not a very hard mechanic to deal with it's just an annoyance like someone sticking the tip of a feather in your ear every couple of seconds. Another negative is the fact that EVERYTHING DOES NOT HAVE TO BE A COMPETITION! The game goes out of it's way to not let you play who want in a multiplayer game with starngers
voteText: which I could over look I guess if it fits the story and all. So why am I fighting everyone for gold and food? This is not fun at all. I want to fight with you not against you

Developers made a game to tickle your nostalgia

reviewText:
In all honesty I've never played the original Gauntlet, or even its supposedly crappy later sequels- just in general I hadn't heard of the game at all till now. So no nostalgia factor for me there.

However, the game itself has solid controls, great graphics and atmosphere, just the right difficulty settings to discourage hack-and-slashing, and is just in general a great, well-polished game. Because of my thirst for/bias for loot and customization, I'd rate it 9/10.

That being said- also absolutely love this for couch co-op reasons. :D

reviewText: Awesome game! Been looking for a game on par with Baldurs Gate: Dark Alliance and I can say that this is up there with it. My cousin and I absolutely loved Baldurs Gate growing up and we were really excited when we found this Gauntlet game because of that. It's really fun two-player and can be beaten in 8 hours. I'd like to see upgrades to the game and more games like this. Just fun, arcade hack-and-slash with upgrades to your character. It's what Diablo 3 should have been, although much simpler than D3, it's also much funner.

reviewText:
Words fail so I'll use numbers instead... 9/10 (I'll leave room for new content and continued support).   ;)

GAUNTLET is a joy to play. The characters all have unique abilities and the game play is F U N.

The amount of TLC that went into this game is obvious and appreciated. THANK YOU ARROWHEAD!

I originally ran and beat the GAUNTLET on Easy and Normal with Questor, and now I'm running WIZARD on Easy.
I briefly tried out Warrior, Valkyrie and Lilith and was hard pressed to choose one because they are all so very well done and such fun to play. iam at around 50 hours right now and still have Warrior, Valkyrie and Lilith to run the GAUNTLET with and thats all Soloing and now they added COLUSSIUM.
Now THAT's replay value like I've NEVER experienced.

Some are complaining about the repetative levels, which I don't understand because each character is so unique it is like playing a new game with each new character...and I have not even tried running the GAUNTLET in a group...lol

The sights and sounds are awesome, the Artwork and style is very inspirational and the gameplay is creative and fun and offers the most replay value of any game I have ever played, and I've played alot.

I hope this gets all the attention it deserves and continues to grow...it's that good.

INVADE THE DARKNESS...but try not to shoot the food

reviewText:
I'm going to be honest. I bought this expecting Guantlet Dark Legacy. What I got was Guantlet: Magika Edition.

Honestly, I don't have any problem with Magika but the fact that this game has absolutely no stat system just ruins it. It's sad attempt at creating some sort of replay value or reward system is just a ridiculously long grind. For example, as a Barbarian I need to kill 20,000 mummies in order to do +10% more damage to mummies. Or I need to take 200,000 points of damage to have an increased HP regen when dropped below 30%. This is not leveling. If I wanted to play a grindy game, there are hundreds of others. If I wanted to play Magika, I would play Magika.

Literally every room you enter follows the following formula:
1. Kill 3 or 4 mobs.
2. Tomb spawns.
3. 2nd Tomb spawns.
4. Kill both Tombs.
5. Get key
6. Open up wall.
7. Rinse and Repeat.

Additionally, there is a death" level every 2nd act where all you do is constantly run away from a being that will instantly slay you. If they wanted to make a game that was similar to Guantlet

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Gauntlet. The first time I played this game I was not an experienced gamer which led me to click 'Thumbs down' on this one. That was a terrible mistake.
They have made some changes that makes the game play more optimized and practical.

+) All characters have their own advantage.
+) Enough kinds of monsters.
+) Enough environmental interruption.
+) Items are about skills and it is promised as you only need to get more gold.
+) Easy mapping.

-) I don't really see the point of breaking healing items and even getting achievement from it.
-) Difficulty balance is bad. Final stage is just way above the bar: No potions, and the healing items will easily be destroyed by you because it spawns where you are while hitting enemies.
-) Sometimes a monster is out of your screen and still attacks you.

reviewText:
I played this game by myself.  It's entertaining, but not satisfying.  Playing with just 2 people magnified this games fun, and the more you have the more of a blast it is.

For people like me who favored Gauntlet: Dark Legacy or Legends, this game is missing the RPG elements.  There's no boosting your base stats, no increasing your health, and magic isn't so consistent.  This game is more dependent on each class playing differently, so picking who you like and their skills is much more vital.

Overall, it's fun with friends.  Don't got friends?  Skip this one, LAN and online are both good.

reviewText: This game is a lot of fun and really stands out in small-scale multiplayer. There are some fun call-backs to the original, but nothing relies on having played them. My nephews, who weren't even around for the originals, have a blast playing this with me. It's fun to get a group of four together to take on the hordes of monsters thrown your way.\n\nThere is a great amount of subtlety to mastering each of the classes. reviewText:
Pros:
+Great co-op game, fun to play with just one other person
+Nostalgic feel of old Gauntlet games (not perfect, but still)
+Easy to pick up, and there are some complex combos you can pull off as wizard
+Runs smoothly

Cons:
-Really short campaign (<8 hours)
-Poor story in campaign (plz hire storytellers I had no attachment to the story at all)

Overall:
Gauntlet is a fun game in terms of gameplay as long as you're with a friend. I never felt like I was grinding and I genuinely looked forward to playing it every night with my bud. However, the campaign was very short, and the story itself could have been told better by a 4-year old. Nothing about the story was interesting, and it was just a very next dungeon

reviewText: The solid and engaging game mechanics of Gauntlet are undermined by its terrible merchant system. Few relics are truly useful and the loadout gear is simply cosmetic. The value and usefulness of gold degrades far too rapidly, dampening the rewards of prolonged play. However, the competitive nature of the cooperative multiplayer sets the stage for some hilariously enjoyable trolling moments. Bring a buddy and put your friendship to the test! In the end, Gauntlet is a bright star that burns fast and is best enjoyed with friends. 8/10

reviewText:
As someone who never played the original Gauntlet titles I was curious to see what made it such a popular series. With 9 titles exisiting dating way back to 1985 I felt I needed to experience this title which dated back through the decades.
Now this iteration of the game, as is customary with the other 9 games in the series (or so the wikipedia page tells me), is a hack'n'slash, dungeon crawler. A formula that I somewhat enjoy, having played things like Torchlight as well as Path of Exile, alongside several other games.
In this title there are a four different classes to choose from, including a warrior (bashy bashy type class), a valkyrie (sort of like the warrior but with a Captain America-like shield which can be thrown), an Elf (who can shoot stuff and throw bombs) and finally a wizard (who has a range of spells and I've also spent most the time playing). Their skills sets are all fairly versatile ranging from the mere axe swinging antics of the warrior to room clearing fireballs with the wizard. You can also buy upgrades for each class by collecting enough gold in each dungeon level. These upgrades range from several relics, which all classes can use, and vary from radial freezing abilities to summoning gargoyles to fight with you. Alongside the relics you can also buy new weapons which grant your character different abilities, class dependant of course. And of course you can buy cosmetic items to change the look of your class. Do you feel the wizard isn't Gandalf-y enough for you? Buy him a pointy hat. Or is the warrior too scantily clad for your tastes? Then buy him some armour. Each class has about three different cosmetic options for both the head and the body. Armours, hoods, capes and hats. Take your pick. You can also unlock capes by beating numerous waves of enemies in the colosseum, which I tell you now is no easy feat.
Overall I'd say this latest iteration of Gauntlet has many of the elements that dungeon crawling, hack'n'slash titles have and need. If you've played the other Gauntlet titles or have played titles such as Torchlight or Diablo etc this is definitley worth a look. Good day!

reviewText: I never played the original gauntlet but with that said growing up me and my friends would always play gauntlet legends on the n64 or at the arcade and we would later move onto gauntlet dark legacy on the gamecube. For me my favorite still after playing gauntlet 2014 is gauntlet dark legacy. The shear amount of characters that dark legacy had and the numerous levels that you could go thru were a treat and i still havent played as all the characters to this day. With that said i was setting my hopes for this game to be somewhat like that and well it isnt at all they feel completely different. Gauntlet 2014 is still a blast to play with friends. The problems being not that many levels but you get what you paid for here there is definitly 20$ worth of value in this game. Back in 2002 i believe i bought dark legacy for 39.99$ and if u compare the games they were worth the price tenfold. Gauntlet 2014 brings a new feature where you can choose your armor and runes which kinda act like skills but serve a better use for the potions then in previous gauntlets. The biggest problem i have with this game is only having four characters and having them color locked like why cant i be a red wizard or a green warrior that was one corner that shouldnt and didnt have to been cut. After spending about 5 hours with gauntlet 2014 i found myself and my friends wanting to go play dark legacy more than what was right in front of our face. Gauntlet 2014 is still a treat with freinds and if uve never played gauntlet before than this is a great buy but if you have fond memories of the older gauntlets u might be better having your friends over and enjoying whats been with us for the last 15 years. In the end Gauntlet 2014 is its own game and is fun with friends. if you and your friends are looking for a game to play that is cheap you cant go wrong and thats why i give this game a 7/10

reviewText:
I played Gauntlet Legends on the N64, and if you've played any other Gauntlet game, you'll enjoy this reboot.

Gauntlet's mechanics, in terms of fighting enemies, attack styles, and movement are fantastic. It doesn't feel clunky, and enemies are predictable but not boring. Each class is bound to fit your playstyle in some way. Even though when compared to Gauntlet Legends, each character doesn't have quite the array of abilities and items to use, this version of Gauntlet makes it work.

As far as the story goes, don't expect much. The story of Gauntlet isn't really one that matters all too much to the game, and there isn't much there. The character's personalities come out a bit in the banter between them at level starts, which is entertaining.

Gauntlet's worth picking up, and dropping a 4-pack for you and your friends. It's bound to bring a lot of fun and tense moments (especially on unfair mode).

reviewText:
This game is good, but with a few improvements it could have been great.

The biggest issue seems to be a terrible lack of content, the game can be completed in just a few hours if you really stretch it and take your time.  The problem is the lack of levels, there are 3 types of arenas each with 3 floors and a boss floor, this gives you just 9 levels and 3 boss fights.  This issue was sort of addressed in the last update adding a colosseum mode where you can battle waves of enemies for new rewards. They also added a new character which cost 5$ to unlock, now this seems like a slap in the face, that's 1/4 of the games price for an extra character.  For a game with such a small amount of cntent it should have been free but I could have justified paying 1-2$ for it but not 5$.

Cons aside this game does provide a good time especially if you have friends to play it with.  This game is all about co-op, it even has couch co-op which was a huge plus for me.  Each character has unique abilities and masteries which makes playing as each character fun and different in some way.  The masteries for each character are what give this game it's replayability factor.  Completing the masteries make your character stronger which make earning the rewards from higher difficulties that much easier.

If your expecting something like Gauntlet Legacy you will be disappointed, but if your looking for a classic arcade style Gauntlet to play with friends then this is the game for you.  I personally don't think that it's worth the 20$ price tag, so I would recommend waiting for a sale.

reviewText:
Let me begin by stating that I have never played any of the original Gauntlet games. Now, with that out of the way let me begin:

I freaking LOVE this game! I am so glad I've found this beautiful little gem. I simply adore this style of game and takes me right back to my youth.
The choice of classes (of which there are 5 at time of writing) are simple yet diverse and upgradable. It has everything a dungeon crawler should have: Monsters, boss's, xp gain and loot. The graphics are nicely done and the soundtrack adds to the atmosphere.
One highlight of this game is its replayability. Each difficulty adds to the game and the more you do the more chance of acquiring those all important achievements.

If you're a fan of Isometric, hack 'n' slash ARPG games then you simply MUST buy this game! You owe it to the developers but more than that you owe it to yourself.

To think that Gauntlet came out a little over four months ago the devs have been busy, adding a new class to the game and a Colosseum mode which pitches you against wave after wave of enemies. This is a game that will keep on giving. If this new iteration of Gauntlet eventually includes all content from previous Gauntlet games then the future of our modern Gauntlet looks very promising indeed. I can't wait to see what happens next.

8/10

reviewText:
I think I picked up this game for just under $6 USD. For that price, it was worth it.

The controls are very tight. The graphics are very well done. Multiplayer 'just works'. There aren't a ton of people playing, but enough to find most game types at any hour of the day.

There is a bit of a grind...when you beat levels you get to keep the gold you picked up. This also drives competitive gold stealing between players which, surprisingly, adds to the game instead of makes it more frustrating.

With your gold you can buy and upgrade a few basic items. Those items do not do anything other than some special power which can only be used if you have potions -- which only exist for the stage you collect them on (stages consist of several levels, four stages to each major act, three major acts make up the entire story of the game). For that reason, the items are very useful -- but not everyone even needs them. One guy with a highly upgraded lute can use all the potions you find as effectively as splitting it up between the players.

There are also some 'level ups' you get which seem more like achievements than levels. They are different for each of the five characters. They consist of things like, kill x number of creatures with a certain attack, die x number of times, lose x amount of health, collect x gold, etc. They grant that specific character special passive abilities such as doing more damage, having shorter cooldowns, etc. However -- the benefits are slight...2% here 5% there...what makes a player able to handle the hardest difficulty mode is more to do with player skill than anything else.

All said and done, the game feels much shorter and less grindy than previous Gauntlet titles -- but the controls are WAY nicer and the graphics and animations are of a much higher quality than any prior gauntlet I've ever played.

It makes for a fun 'pick up and play' casual arcade game that is fun for shorter periods of time. It has more replayability than I expected for having so few levels, but even so, there really are very few levels.

Thankfully, the replayability comes from trying to perfect your handling of your character. And each of the five characters do seem to play rather differently and are pretty well balanced.

The Elf is good at sniping, bombing large groups of mobs and roll dodging.
The Valkyrie has a powerful shield and some dash and shield throw abilities that make her good at quick skirmish attacks.
The Barbarian is able to charge and do some larger AOE attacks and kick more butt with melee.
The Wizard is challenging, as you have to memorize 9 different key combinations to switch to the appropriate spell at any given moment. If you screw up, he can die very quickly as he doesn't have a 'basic attack.' That being said, he's incredibly powerful if played correctly.
And Lilith (some kind of necromancer) can only be played if you bought the expansion which costs about as much as the base game. She seems to have some fantastic abilities that seem poached from the other 4 classes along with the ability to summon a bunch of undead as meat shields.

One tactic I found very useful is with Lilith and the Wizard. Lilith gets into a corner near a monster spawner and summons undead. The mage teleports behind the undead wall and then casts frost beam at the spawner. Frost beam does more damage the longer it is active and since you won't have to run away because you've got a nice meat shield you knock down spawners very quickly.

For ~$6 this game is worth it. The lack of levels and content is a big negative. No user created levels was a mistake as Gauntlet is supposed to have a billion levels...and this would have been a way to do it. This is a shame because the graphics, and fluid controls of the game means it has a very solid base to build from.

reviewText:
Thinking of buying Gauntlet?
I have been playing it with 2 RL friends, and i have a few online friends i havent played yet with, and it has been a blast so far, completely worth the 20$.

Do not buy this game to be a lone wolf, or play by yourself. Do not play this game if you are going to use the matchmaking system. Its decent, the system works ish. But there is no Communication  chat/voice at all in this game. Which is sorta cool feeling, but doesnt work out.

If you play with some friends LAN style, or over a Voice chat, you will have endless fun. I have been setting World records with me 2 friends non-stop, feel free to check out some of my screenshots if you need to.

The characters dont feel very deep at first, but the way the leveling up works...is weird but feels ok in the long run. You get some talents by playing naturally that add just the right amount of depth to make it feel balanced. Characters feel sorta balanced, Warrior might be a little subpar. Either way, if you're playing with friends you will have fun. Wizard is Hard but good. Valk seems great. I play archer, i love it.

Mastery level you get just by dieing or killing. They are like ingame achievements that .... give you bonus's. It feels backwards to get a bonus to die less,... by getting killed but it works.

Stats/records make things fun.

The game feels a little short. probably 10 hours if you play normal. The difficulties are fun though, and the replay does feel fun.

The relic system is ....alright? It could be tweeked.

The game is exactly what you think it is though. And its a lot of fun. 9/10 if you have friends to play with.
I'd like to see some additions and patches though.

reviewText:
I was worried that this remake would not live up to the classics... Many hours I put into Gauntlet 1 and 2 on the arcade machines down at the fish-and-chip shop as a child, so when I saw they were doing a remake I was skeptical, but I have to say - despite certain changes they've made, this game is pretty damn fun.

It CAN be played as a single-player experience which ends up being a very arcade-themed version of Diablo, really. But this is best enjoyed as a multiplayer game, even if it's just with one other person.

I'm genuinely having a lot of fun with this.

reviewText:
A remake of the original gauntlet, with a different take on it. It's different to the original gauntlet so bear that in mind.

- Use either an xbox controller with this or keyboard, other gamepads may need xinput or something (check forums)

reviewText:
Gauntlet in the 80's arcade was fantastic fun.  There were usually lots of people around to join in on the fun, but for whatever reason this one just didn't hold the nostalgic trip I was looking for.  Don't get me wrong though.  If you're into gauntlet you definitely need to check this title out.  GREAT fun for some couch co-op when you have friends over.

There's LOTS of in game achievements to grab for each of the characters it provides.  There's bosses throughout and an end game boss too.  I found the Elf to be the easiest character to play as.  He's quick and ranged which helps with the mass amount of enemies charging your direction.  I only played the Slayer Edition so I can't comment on pre-2.0, but I've heard version 1.0 was a lot better and many people miss it.

There's 30ish stages to play through and it does have online mp and couch coop.  It'll take roughly 6 hours to beat solo with one play through, but once again the coop is where it's at.  Grab it on sale.  Fun for a limited time.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I loved the Gauntlet games when i was a young boy.
We always played this game with a few people in the local arcadehall.
I remember that the person who played the elf just had to die.
So funny back then (and even now, hahaha)

After some years the Gauntlet was revived in a 3D version on the first xbox and PS2 consoles.
The games still are very fun and addictive to play but never (in my opinion) got the attention it deserves.

Now, years later there is finally a new Gauntlet game.
When this game was released it was riddled with bugs and the controls where a bit unresponsive at times so after some frustrating moments i quickly decided i was stopping and moving to other game horizons.
After a few months and loads of patches and updates i tried Gauntlet again and now most real problems where finally solved.
The best way to play is with some friends.
Players can join in using internet and local couch co-op.

Graphics are functional but for this day of age, nothing special.
Sound is pretty decent and never get's annoying.
Storywise there is not much there but that's not what makes this a timeless gameseries.

The gameplay is good and fun.
Just play this a while in multiplayer and if you have not played a Gauntlet game yet, you'll probably be hooked for a long time.
I can honestly say that this is a game that i will never really get bored of.
A few weeks ago a revamped Gauntlet Slayer edition was released that updates the game with loads of extra's.
People who already owned Gauntlet got this updated version FREE.

I would rate this an 6,5 out of 10 in singleplayer and in multiplayer about 8,6 out of 10.

If you want a solid (multi)player game that is worth every penny it costs,
There is no excuse not to try and buy this game.

ps: Let the Elf die!! That should teach him/her to select the Elf. (older gamers will remember why.)

reviewText:
Great rendition of the original. Very fun after a few hours, can't speak to the replay value as I haven't been through the whole game yet, but it is well designed and haven't ran into any bugs.

Character building is fun, but doesn't necessarily improve the character, rather change the abilities. This is interesting, but I find myself going back to my original weapons because I like them and am more used to them.

Fun for local and online co-op with friends. Definitely worth the sale price.

It's a shame that they're stopping development. I was hoping for some more content being that the story line is kind of quick. I was also hoping they would make some more characters.

Overall, I'd say don't pay full price but DEFINITELY pick it up when it's on sale. It's a really fun dungeon arcade that you will be happy you experienced.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game.  If you look at it and think it might even be a little fun, get it.  You will not be disappointed.

It feels very much like the classic Gauntlet games in that it has plenty of enemies, spawners, food that is needed badly, and so forth.  However it's also a highly tactical game that rewards creative play.  Each of the classes plays quite differently and skill with any of them can let you completely dominate enemies.

This is one my favorite games for both couch coop and over-the-Internet coop and everything inbetween thanks to drop-in/drop-out multiplayer and with the endless dungeon mode there's no reason to stop playing.

reviewText:
Hella good arcade classic game. Even if you dont know it, it's fun to pick up and play with friends. Not complicated but can be tricky or hard at times, takes a bit of skill, knowledge and teamwork. The ways to kill your allies on  accident or purpose is fun. Shooting food is mean but if someone is being a weenie and you kill their food, well maybe they wont act like a twinkie anymore. Extra fun if you got 3 other friends but the matchmaking works VERY well you're in a game of your similar level very quickly and you can learn a lot by playing with new people. It's on sale, buy it, heck, buy the 4 pack and ask some friends if they'd be interested in playing.

This game for sure plays better on a controller. I like to use mouse and keyboard for mostly every game but this game just flows much better with it, I feel it's easier to aim and not as clunky.

4.5/5

reviewText: The Developers have managed to pull off a wonderful feat with this reboot. They have captured the nostalgia of the original while providing new and exciting gameplay. The characters are gold and the voices perfectly humorous. The combos are all unique and drastically change the feel of gameplay while special items allow you to customize your style even further. I also have to compliment the devs on having a day one launch game where everything just worked. I played with my wife, my three year old son, and three controllers. If you are considering purchasing this game for the nostalgia or the local co-op it is twenty dollars well spent.

reviewText:
This isn't Gauntlet.

This is a modern version of SmashTV, pretending to be Gauntlet.

This is perfectly fine, if you like SmashTV... which I do.

The path you take through the game is fairly linear. As you go through the game, you will constantly find yourself in self-sealing mini-arena rooms that suddenly spawn monster generators, spamming you with low-level mobs from multiple sides that can be taken out in 1 or 2 hits, and throwing a few medium or high-powered threats in with the swarms of cannon-fodder attackers. The rooms will remain locked tight until all the mobs and generators are destroyed, and only then can you proceed. In between clearing the rooms, you'll pick up treasure, food, and potions which fuel your purchased relic power-ups. The rooms, in any of the three worlds, will all look and feel very similar to each other with little variations. The pattern of kiting around the enemies, using speed to lead them into manageable groupings, and then taking them out when you have the tactical advantage will remain constant throughout the whole game.

Even the cheesy, smarmy dialog between your character and the dungeon controller is similar to SmashTV.

And, its fun... its actually a LOT of fun...

... but its not Gauntlet.

Classic Gauntlet, at its core, has just one simple game mechanic: Control the pacing.

From the second you pressed start, your life force was a timer. Enemies reduced your time. Death drained your time. Traps stole some time and stunned you in place for a few precious seconds. The mazes, shifting walls, and teleporters all disoriented and frustratingly led you down the wrong paths, eating up time. The destrucible walls forced you to spend time to get through them. Hidden objects in plain-looking walls made you trade time for their advantages. Doors that led to only treasure made you spend your time in looting. Being It" drew the monsters to you
date: devouring time. Special potions and abilities either assisted or made things more difficult
recommended: costing you those few seconds to decide if they were worth the time. Food replenished just a little time.\n\nEvery new dungeon level had all of the monster generators in place at the start
hoursPlayed: pumping out mobs every second
voteText: and you had to manipulate the swarms by shooting
helpfulPercent: hand-to-hand battling
votesHelpful: sniping through corners
votesTotal: absorbing the damage
votesFunny: or evading past them if it was advantageous... all to get to the exit with as much time as possible left in your life-force
commentsCount: and then do it again
column16: and again
column17: and again until the game was over in a pile of bones and keys.\n\n... and this new game has absolutely NONE of that in it. There is no sense of urgency
column18: and very little to push your pace faster than you care to go.\n\nYour life bar never drains on its own. You can take 2-5 hits before dying. Food will fill the life bar toward its maximum
column19: but no further.\n\nYou can kite and circle your foes for as long as you want
column20: in fact its to your advantage to do so as killing multiple mobs in continual succession gives you a bonus to your Kill-Streak
column21: which helps to build up points toward Skull-Tokens
column22:
your Continues.

Exploring is somewhat pointless... there are no secret walls that aren't visibly marked with cracks and nearby convenient barrels for blasting them open.

There is just the somewhat direct path through the dungeon levels with pre-scripted encounters in arena rooms
column23: with just enough keys to make it through the level you are on
column24: and no random encounters to speak of. Major swarms of enemies can't really wander out of their areas because the generators don't appear until you enter the room and trigger the encounter
column25: so your ability to use choke-points and the dungeon layout is limited
column26:
at best.

This game is GREAT and a LOT of fun at what it really is... SmashTV dressed up to look and feel like Gauntlet.

... its just not Gauntlet.

(Incidentally

reviewText:
This game should not be what it is. The makers of Magicka, that ridiculous game of mages keying in button commands and blowing each other up and sometimes blowing enemies up ply their craft at Gauntlet, the age old and yawn-inducingly simple arcade game of throwing swords at hordes of monsters and hopefully not the food.

This SHOULD be utter mindless drivel. Worthy of laughs when played with friends and not much else.

But it simply is not. This Gauntlet has taken the concept of wading into a dungeon filled with thousands of enemies and honed it, tightened it into something beautiful. Hacking, slashing, charging, shooting, blasting, it all feels great, it feels tactical. All four (Plus one quite fun DLC character) characters have their own movesets and each of them play quite differently. Even when all you need to do is mash the attack button you always have a game of footsies to play with the enemies to avoid being surrounded, and you always have at least one or two brutally satisfying moves to whip out. The elf drops bombs and charges sniper shots. The warrior's heavy attack is best used sparingly, but his tazmanian devil spin does double duty to save him from tight spots and to just feel cool as you turn a bunch of enemies into red mist. The valkyrie's lance attack hits with brutally satisfying force. The elf tumbles, drops bombs, charges up power arrows, and can even fire bomb arrows. And the wizard... oh boy. He plays Magicka lite and, if you can memorize about a half dozen spell inputs, you can control the game. Freezing, fireballs, flaming dashes. He is not my thing, but it is always nice to have him.

This is a real action game. Satisfying hits, enemies with windup attacks that must be dodged and dealt with. It's perfectly fun solo and even more fun with the game's breezy drop in drop out online coop. Just open your game to the world and you will pick up people signing up to play with you as you explore.

The game itself is short, but replayable. Three difficulties, a colosseum mode for straight up combat. Each character has a perk tree that is only fed by grind, but beyond the easy early perks, very few provide a noticeable effect on gameplay. And the game itself is just fun to play. It invites just picking up every now and again and bashing some monsters, alone, with friends, or with random partners online.

I wish I had not been so skeptical of Gauntlet when it released. Every preconception I had suggested that this game would never and could never be as good as it was. This one is truly a pleasant surprise.

The DLC character is worth paying for too, if only as a backup to avoid joining a 3 man game with only your weakest character available to play.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is modern Gauntlet. You could call it a remake, but it's not really that. It's so much better. It's a dungeon crawler and arena twin-stick shooter. It's Gauntlet on steroids, but it hasn't lost that old-school charm. Best played with others, especially when you get into Hard and above.

The biggest flaws I've seen are a lack of variation on encounters. This was a chance for the team to take Gauntlet even farther, but they stuck with something more tried and true. Granted, it's been refined so that the annoyances of a generation ago aren't still here. There's also a new relic system to give you some sense of progression other than making it through the dungeon. But at it's core, it's the same sets of encounters over and over again, and when you've seen them once, you've seen them.

My other big gripe is that the loadouts do nothing but change how your character is dressed. Certainly they could have given some other bonus, especially with some of them requiring you beat certain levels on specific difficulties. At the very least, they could have made the loadouts be more visually interesting, because right now, they're a bit boring. I'm not really interested in spending my hard-earned gold on them for such little gain.

That doesn't make the game not great though. The normal campaign will last you about 6-8 hours depending on your abilities and that's not bad. Add in additional difficulty levels and you've got a competent remake. The added charm of the announcer quipping about Warrior needing food, badly, or the food being shot by the clever wizard harken back to the game we all know and love.

The story is a bit drab and predictable, but you're not here for the story, so who gives a ♥♥♥♥? The visuals are great, the sound and music fit the game perfectly, and the difficulty scales well. All-in-all, the Arrowhead team has done a great job! I look forward to Gauntlet 2.

reviewText:
This is a modern take on Gauntlet from the Nintendo Entertainment System released in 1987, a game which was also very fun and if you have an NES, might be worth looking for.

You play as one of four classes (Valkyrie <3) , alone or with up to 3 friends, and make your way through difficult hordes of enemies in dungeons and fight massive bosses.  Dodge traps, discover secret rooms, gain new spells and armor through a shop at the main hub, and more.

This game definitely has some flaws.  The video settings are a bit lacking.  Also my computer has a hard time running it in certain areas, even though it doesn't look like a very demanding game.  However my enjoyment of the game has surpassed my annoyance of any problems it has, and I am hoping they are working hard to fix them.  It's definitely worth playing.

reviewText: Very solid mostly-coop game. Why mostly? Because there's a competitive aspect to it when it comes to scoring. Gold pickups are shared, everything else isn't. In fact, you can pretty much pull all sorts of ♥♥♥♥ery like hogging the food and potions, destroying the food, triggering environmental hazards perhaps out of spite for that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ who got you to drop the crown. The crown is pretty inconsequential, it just adds to your score at the end of a level and gives everyone something to brag about.\n\nYou get skull coins for killing special mobs, and it's these skull coins that count as your continue coin" whenever somebody dies. It's shared among the party so once they're all used up
date:
anyone who dies gets a much longer respawn timer (at least in normal difficulty).

Much of the levels involve very simple puzzles and killing lots of monsters. You'll have to work together to destroy spawners but also kill the monster while someone else kites them around.

Potions are limited use items that let you activate one of two relics you've equipped which are special abilities. You can activate them via LB or RB (Xbox controller) but the game doesn't really teach you this at the start.

The equipment are all cosmetic

reviewText:
As you can see, I recommend this game, but it comes with a few caveats.

If you're wanting an experience similar to the classic Gauntlet games, or even like the newer 3D versions like Dark Legacy, this is probably not the game you're looking for. You want to go look at Hammerwatch instead. Trust me.

That's not to say this is a bad game, but it has a lot of short comings, and many gameplay elements of Gauntlet have been dropped, some new ones added, and it just doesn't really feel like the Gauntlet I grew up with. Which to be fair, is one of my favorite games of all time. Both the classic versions and the 3D ones.

Dungeon floors aren't randomized, and while I know this wasn't a feature in the other games in this series, in the current game market this just feels lazy. I'm already getting sick of running the same (very few) levels over and over with the only change being which character I play as. Secrets and the like are also mysteriously lacking.

We might as well talk about those characters, actually. Each one plays differently, and not just in regard to how they attack or what skills they use. They fundamentally control different from each other. The Wizard, for instance, mixes two elements together to create one of a number of spells. The Elf plays similar to a twin stick shooter character, akin to Smash TV or Beat Hazard. The Warrior and Valkyrie are kind of similar, but the Valkyrie has the ability to tank, and defend the party with her shield.

She's also very overpowered compared to the other characters (in my opinion at least) once you learn to use her effectively. A lot of people don't even play her as a tank, and instead spear rush nonstop, which does a lot of damage very quickly. This makes it easy to lead a game in points from having a really high kill score compared to the other players. This is especially true if they haven't learned how to use their character yet.

Each character also has a set of challenges that come with them, which unlock little passive buffs when you complete them. Kill 2000 mummies, get +10% damage against them. Things like this. Progress is not shared across characters, so if you have been mainly playing as one class, then join a multiplayer game where that class is already taken, you'll be missing all the unlocked bonuses for that character, as well as any relics they have bought.

There are a couple minor bugs and AI quirks (enemies can't walk under bridges that are on a higher level than them?), but nothing that is a huge issue. I've only had one instance of the game bugging out and putting me in a state where I could not progress because of a gate not opening as it should have.

It's a co-op game, but not really. What I mean is that it is in your best interest (even if it's not the parties best interest) to hog everything for yourself, let other people die so you can steal the gold they drop, and generally act like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to people you don't know.  While I really don't have a problem with the game allowing that, it has never been how I played Gauntlet with my friends. You always do a lot better if you work as a damn team, even if your score won't be as high from being selfish.

Joining online games is a real chore, and it usually takes me upwards of ten attempts before it finally joins a game without either giving me a timeout error or saying the game is already full.

There's no way to communicate with the other players, outside of four nearly useless emotes that are mapped to the D-pad.  Maybe this was the intent, but when I can just shift+tab to talk to the people via Steam's built in chat, this just feels like an oversight and creates an extra step (and one that takes me out of the game) to offer advice. The biggest problem with not being able to communicate, to me at least, is that it is really bothersome to try to figure out which level everyone wants to do when starting a multiplayer game.

Again, this isn't a bad game, but if you really want something like Gauntlet, go pick up Hammerwatch instead. Otherwise, I'd really wait for a sale for this one.

reviewText:
WARNING!!!
If you enjoy Gauntlet Games please read this!!!

First off i am very disappointed with this version of Gauntlet, This fell WAY short of Gauntlet Legends 64 in many ways.
Quick rundown

1. The leveling system - gone, no more yellow wizard has leveled up. And no leveling up to 1-99. your the same level all the time.

2. Game is way shorter then the version from 1998, if anything it should have been longer. can be beaten in less then 3 hours alone.

3. Uncreative level design, no different worlds , just doors with numbers. Plus most levels looked alike to me, either it was in a dark cave or in hell is seemed. What happened to like, Mountain, Castle, Town, Cathedral,  Battlefield, and the Underworld.  And having to travel to get there.

4.  Not being able to make yourself stronger sucks, you have to buy relics that you can't even use unless you find a potion. and all the armor/weapon upgrades are just for show. ruining any reason for me to play the game again. meaning ZERO replay value to me.

5. This game honestly looks like a not free version of Crimson Alliance, except Crimson Alliance it better in everyway. Making it, in my opinion a ripe off of that game.

I had such high hopes for this game and i felt they really dropped the ball on this one. I was really looking forward on my down time to play this game a few hours a week and level up all the classes to see how they played when maxed out. And that will not be happening without a leveling system, making no reason for me to play the game again after i beat it. And all the uncreative level design also really ruined the experience even more. then finding out i can't even upgrade my characters, except relics which are one of the dumbest features that are upgraded with gold not XP. And to top it of, to find out it is like a rip off of another game and not even like its former self. Tops it off for me. And this makes this the worst game i ever spent my money on with steam. So Save your money if you expect to have a flashback to 1998 gaunlet series.

Over all my opinion on this game, is it's bad and thats that.

:(

reviewText:
Don't let the rather drab, brown screenshots put you off; this is a game that is both dripping with personality and that is remarkably true to the original arcade experience while simultaneously bringing it bang up to date for a modern audience.

It's not trying to be something it's not. It's not trying to be Diablo or any kind of RPG; it's trying to be a modern-day Gauntlet. And it's doing so remarkably well. The four characters all play in a distinctly unique fashion -- far more so than in the original game -- and in local co-op in particular it's just a joy to crawl some dungeons together, battling over the loot, the crown and the inevitable arguments over who is the best" on the end-level summary screen.

I couldn't say if it would be quite so fun in single-player as I haven't tried it as of the writing of this review
date: but if you have at least one friend willing to fight alongside you
recommended: I can happily give this a solid recommendation."

reviewText:
Game is great.

Don't get me wrong it has flaws and if you were a fan of the original or the remakes and updates you will find enough similar things in this game to make you smile but not enough to feel like a carbon copy of what came before it.
Netcode is great as well.

As far as leaderboards go, WB have wiped it once but if you are used to steam you know that any non-vac leader board has been hacked...Except for Sanctum. Maybe that game was too obscure but it is the only game (and I own a lot!) that I have seen with a non hacked leaderboard but I digress.

If you want to have fun with you and some friends, this is the game! Be catious when joining randoms though as you can grief in this game pretty easily I'm afraid.

Sound, music, controls, they are all good or great and the fact that each class plays radically different is amazing! I was skeptical at first but it really works well giving true variety rather than palette swapping.

Hope you enjoy.

reviewText:
I bought through this game thinking I could relive some fond memories of the couch co-op adventures I've had on Gauntlet: Dark Legacy on my PS2 many years ago, an error on my end, as this is a remake of the original gauntlet, that being said i still enjoyed this game, and it was a lot of fun to blast through the campaign in multiplayer.  Only major downside i can think of is that i beat it in 6 hours and the final boss was rather underwhelming.

But the important part: Should you buy it?   That depends, if you want something that's on par with the original Gauntlet or even Dark Legacy in terms of length of gameplay and the amount of levels, number of various classes to try out in each playthrough, you might be dissapointed as there are only the original 4, though theres a new dlc for the necromancer class. If you want something thats very similar to the very original gauntlet but it's replay value relies on completing the same content on harder difficulties sort of like diablo (Though diablo has more class customisation and variation) then you might enjoy this game.

All in all I had fun with it for the short time it lasted, i don't think i'll be replaying it anytime, unless with a group of friends maybe.  I'd give the game a 7/10   It's not bad, just could've done alot better.

reviewText:
I do love the game.  While the fun hack and slash co-op feel of the original is wonderfully preserved, the new reboot adds new depth through diversifying the playstyles of the classes.  The in-game interaction between the 4 heroes who are old friends (since 1985) is endearing and nostalgic, the music and stages are beautiful.  Controls feel nice and fluid, and the difficulty levels are well balanced.

While many of the negative reviews are true (ie: short content, lack of communication features, need for better matchmaking), the developers of the game do monitor the forums for feedback.

Bottom line is: it is great fun, and there's more to come.

Edit (Dec 1, 2014): as of this edit, patch 1.04 had gone live, improving many features such as the matchmaking, in-game communication, and rebalancing the classes.  I recommend the game even more highly now.

reviewText: The nostalgia is strong with this one, I was ten years old in 1985 & my favourite game at the local Arcades was Gauntlet. I played this to death with my friends and this remake does the original justice. Another game from the same era was Smash TV, it involved kiting yourself around avoiding waves of incoming enemy's. There are many similarities between the two games, both involved avoiding zerging waves of enemies which created a high thrill seat of your pants" gameplay. Gauntlet can be compared to many games including Diablo and other action RPG's though it is still very unique in its style. This was a genre defining game that has never been equalled and without doubt is a must play for all Action RPG fans. I give this remake a 9/10
date: it is very true to the original and that's what makes it great.\n\nWARNING: This is not a game for those who need Epic L00t as there is none. The gear you unlock by completing certain stages at different difficulty levels is purely cosmetic. Relics and Mastery levels add some abilities and increased power to your characters but these are the only none cosmetic customisations available."

reviewText: If you are looking for storytelling and atmosphere this is not the game for you. The game follows the mechanic of old NES gauntlet - go around the dungeon, opening doors with keys, eating (and destroying) food, and exploding summoning stones. Oh, and killing evil things. LOTS of evil things. SWARMS of evil things, if you dare play on Hard and Unfair modes. That said, I LOVE it. It's an actual skill challenge, and you have to be analytical about it. Button mashing will not get you very far. For me it was a game very worth of its price. I hope the developers keep creating more content, specially more levels.

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Overall Rating: 8/10
Gameplay Rating: 8/10
Accessibility Rating: 9/10

NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).  If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!

General GameplayGauntlet is a single player or co-op experience!  This tribute to the older games in its lineage reawakens the fun, top-down dungeon crawling, horde-destroying genius of the original games.

Though a bit linear and slightly redundant, Gauntlet is still entertaining in both single and co-op modes.  The Colosseum mode brings together 4 players in classic arcade fashion.

The achievements in Gauntlet come for both good and bad events, such as collecting gold or dying, and all make your character just a little better.

Replayability
As a co-op game with friends, however, Gauntlet's outstanding history shines through and the game becomes fun, amusing, and challenging.

Additional replayability comes from trying to complete the game and all achievements with all of the character types.  If you're a completionist, you may enjoy trying to get this one done.  Just bring a friend!

General Accessibility
Accessibility Options
Gauntlet has sound settings controls for master volume, music, effects, and dialogue, as well as captions (subtitles).

When you start the game, it goes straight to the main menu, so you can set captions on before any events happen.

For gamers with mobility issues, Gauntlet's primary controls are game controller, but it works with keyboard and mouse just as well.  All keys can be rebound to suit your needs.

Subtitles & Captions
Captions in Gauntlet are great!  Gauntlet is not a very dialogue-rich game, so most of what is said is flavor text, but it all seems to be there.

Pros:
- Captions for characters are colored according to that character's color (green for elf, for example), and captions from the evil mastermind leading the gauntlet are white.
- Captions are easy to read in large font across the bottom of the screen.

Cons:
- Captions do not indicate who is speaking by name.  Only a *minor* problem because they are colored.

Chatting/Communicating
Gauntlet supports in-game chat and colors text according to which character you're playing.

---
Visit Games Reviews for the Deaf/HoHhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/gamereviewsforthedeaf

reviewText:
Do not buy this if you do not have friends (or can't manage to match their play times) to play CO-OP with regularly.  This game sucks and is really boring when playing alone.

+ Fun with Friends
+ The synergy between the 4 Classes/Charachters is very good.

- Limited Classes
- Limited upgrades
- Auto-upgrades, you can't choose your own masteries
- No voice chat
- Bad soundtrack
- Matchmaking into a lobby feature sucks
- You get rewarded if your teammate dies (you can steal his gold)
- Repetitve, only 3 types of dungeons. Go into a room --> Creeps will start spawning around a tower --> Kill the towers avoiding the creeps.
- Found 3 game breaking bugs (had to restart the whole level) in a session of 3 hours.

TL;DR: The game is unpoloshied. It's quality is literally worse than F2P games (like Path of Exile) and is definetly not worth $20. Not even worth $10 IMO.

reviewText: The aesthetic on the whole is bright, cartoony, and lighthearted, fitting pretty well with the dialogue, except for the Valkyrie. The gameplay does resemble the old gauntlet arcade games pretty well, with massive swarms of enemies to hack and cleave through. The problem I have with it is that the multiplayer aspect is so emphasized that it feels like the game was designed on the assumption that you would play it with three friends in a living room. This is bad for two reasons; one: anything at all is fun if you're playing it with your friends around a table of pizza and beer, and two: if that's how the game is intended to be played, why was it even ported to the PC, which is the worst possible platform for party gaming. Add to this a needlessly grindy system of magic upgrades and a selection of cosmetics you will never see in the game that feels like the game was made to be a vehicle for selling microtransactions, and you've got a game with a lot of problems that would still be decent casual game except that the dodging moves for the elf and the valkyrie are not only tricky to aim in the direction you want to actually go, but do not move the character a reliable distance and cause framedrops if you use them when there are a lot of enemies on screen, which is of course the situation in which you would be spamming dodge roll or spear thrust. Frankly, I would trade in the havoc physics for decapitated heads and half the polygon count for a game that could maintain a decent framerate.\n\n-Also unplayable without an XBOX controller.-

It seems that instead of serving us up complete effluent they have instead managed some kind of plumbing tomfoolery which has resulted in the effluent being mixed with cool, pure water. The resulting fluid can fill a glass but it is possibly not a glass one would choose to drink from.

Some of the benefits of the game...

1) Graphics are nice and (vaguely) evocative of the original game. Nothing looks bad and the game runs well. Everything looks reasonable for an arpg, tbh. reviewText:
Gauntlet
Rating: 5 / 10

(Played this game as a single player so this small review has been based upon that.)

The Gauntlet is an action-rpg primarily focused on co-op party, but going in as a solo player is no problem. The game is a dungeon crawler so that's basically the only environment you encounter which becomes very boring after a while. As this is controller friendly, you loot and pick up items just by walking over them, and don't have to worry about an inventory because there isn't any. Upgrades of your equipment you buy at your local shop for the money you collect while grinding through the levels.

There is no story at all, so you don't have to make choices or encounter npc's. The game focuses 100% on combat and when you're solo in the game this feels a bit lonely. The graphics aren't that great, the rendering distance is a bit too far. What I like is that you can dodge missiles and make use of your class specific skills. Crossing a dangerous floor is easier as a ranger than a warrior, just because you are quicker. Sound logical but in ARPG that isn't always the case.

Fighting is clicking the right buttons. Warrior is the easiest, mage the most difficult as you have to remember button sequences which sounds a bit dated to me. Press this, than this and finally this to cast a spell. Very arcade yes, but hardly modern.

As a solo player I can't recommend this because it is too boring and bland. There are lots of better action rpg's in the world to devote your time to. As a party game I can imagine it can be fun to play. For a while that is as the variety seems a little low.

reviewText:
This game is the classic top-down hack-and-slash with a lot of great flow to it, and a pretty visual theme to boot! This will ♥♥♥♥ you off to no end, in the most fun way imaginable! The characters all have their own very unique playstyle and skillset, which makes mastering your own style of play very easy but not intimidating enough to make you soley stick to one character. (Haven't gotten the Necromancer yet, so I don't have any input on him.)

The Warrior is very well done, and he can definitely deal a ton of damage while staying nimble enough to aovid huge mobs.

The Valkyrie is fun to use and extremly useful in a pinch when you're playing with 2 or more characters. Though the shield is a bit a awkword to figure out at first. Balancing throwing and blocking takes time.

The elf is just flawless. While he can't hurt the monster spawner with basic attacks, the bomb arrow more than makes up for that. His ability to roll around and laugh at enemy damage is hilarious.

Saved my personal favourite for last. The mage is extremly fine tuned. With nine spells - including slows, freeze spell, an aoe explosive, a shield, and arcing lightning - The developers had a lot of fun making him. I'll say that trying to remember the element combination (any two combined of fire, lightning, and ice) takes a minute to get the hang of, after that he decimates waves and spawners. It's almost unfair, but he does have a bit of a health handicap. So it evens out.

Would I buy it again? Hell yeah! And another! Maybe another, but that'd be it. I'd have four online friends, it'd be perfect!

As much as I would have loved to say I liked this... I do not. I was a BIG fan of the originals, and was expecting something along the lines of those... what I feel i recieved from this was a slowed down version with funky controls and just no real humor behind it like the originals had.

This... I just cant recommend to anyone one, especially fans of the original gauntlet games. Even with other people this just feels boring and bland. the sound is nothing spectacular, and i feel like the graphics from the old ones are actually better than what we got here. sure this looks cleaner, but gauntlet has always been known for having a good ammount of grittiness to its graphics. it in no way, shape or form was ment to look pretty but ment to be fun. and, like the course i see many new games coming out these days... this one went for cleaner, prettier look, but dumbed down gameplay which leaves alot to be desired.

One more thing, and this one is strictly to those expecting to enjoy the wizard... I hope you like button combinations... because you have to actually come up with a button combo in order to use your spells and then launch them with the directional attack keys/stick if you are using a controller. it just gets too tedious to really even bother.

reviewText:
This game is okay.

If you're looking at this title, you're probably hoping for another Legends or Dark Legacy, though. Alas, that's not what we got. Not that this is necessarily a BAD game, but Gauntlet filled a certain niche that many of us wanted to relive in a more modern title. However, we got another Seven Sorrows; another new flavor that nobody asked for. But, an acquired taste to some, maybe.
Don't you dare play this alone because you will drop it in under an hour.

Also if you like playing Invoker in Dota, check out the Wizard.

reviewText:
When is Gauntlet not like Gauntlet?  When it's this version.

This has more in common with a multi-player version of Diablo than it does with Gauntlet.

I played Gauntlet in the arcades back in the day, when it was new, and eagerly awaited it's release for home computers, including Atari ST and zx spectrum and a few others that were around at the time.  My friends and I enjoyed the conversion and played it for many hours.

Then came Gauntlet 2 and we were excited all over again, especially  when it was released for home enjoyment, and we all spent our waking hours wandering around with different coloured versions of each of the four characters, with Red elf and yellow wizard and blue wizard and green valkyrie, it was a good time had by all without the limitations of one character type availalbe, and often we'd play as four versions of the same character to see how it played.

Now after a few other releases of gauntlet and it's clones over the years on consoles and home computers, we come to this version.

While I wouldn't say it's a bad game at all, to expect it to be like either of the first two Gauntlet games is to meet with dissapointment, and it really does have a lot more in common with diablo 1 or 2, and Diablo's spawned children than the golden Gauntlet of happiness that I still remember clearly and dearly.

There are certain things that tie this title loosely to the Gauntlet of it's title, like 4 characters named after the Gauntlet characters. Food that's fragile and can be destroyed accidentally, and the fact that it all takes place in a dungeon.  Certain sounds and phrases are very similar to the original too.  But that's it for similarity really. Anything else is from Diablo.  There aren't mazes filled with spawners of varying strengths 1-3 (though there are occassional spawners scattered here and there), and there are potions but they are needed to power artifacts which you buy with gold, outside of the levels you play through.  The speech is of course clear and everything, but it is missing the dramatic tone that the original sampled speech used to have, and doesn't fit so well.   The only characters that shoot anything off are the elf and wizard, with the rest needing to use secondary abilities to do anything beyond bashing/stabbing the monsters.  And on the subect of the wizard, I hope you like pressing combinations of buttons/keys to use an ability, out of all the ones he has hidden.

Muti-player is very hit and miss, in that you might find good players that work together, and with due caution, or more usually find completely selfish players who get the party killed and have no other care but for their own selves and getting all the money and food for themselves.  Unfortunately there are far more of the second type than the first, which makes for a less than wonderful experience in multi-player, and has made it so that I am hesitant to even consider playing multi-player when (if) I play gauntlet.  Too many people playing it as though the other gamers are just tagging along, and then blaming them for being noobs when they die because the selfish individual has taken all the money/food/potions.

All in all, I am not so willing to recommend this version as a Gauntlet game, but I am willing to recommend it as a diablo clone that's cheaper than the average game these days, and I'd not recommend it to any of my friends if they played Gauntlet and were looking for a modern version to have fun with, though hey.. it's a game to fill the quiet moments of the day with dungeons and monsters.

reviewText:
I really liked the old Gauntlet.
This one requires teamwork and a lot of trial and error. You will die, very easily.
The classes are varied and fun to play with. My favorite is the Elf. It runs really well with never a dip in frames or stutters when the mobs fill the screen.
There isn't too much replay value. You do unlock different powers and cosmetic gear but thats about it. Playing with friends wether online, local or even both is where the meat of the game is. As of this writing I had no problem finding people to p[lay with. It's fun and worth the $20 price. Just don't expect the depth of Hammerwatch or Torchlight.
If you like dungeon crawlers and co-op games this is a goodie.
8/10

reviewText: Surprisingly addictive, especially with 4 players. Also surprisingly difficult. Pretty basic controls, not much on the customization side, but mastery levels add more replay value on top of each class having different gameplay mechanics.

reviewText:
Challenging without being awkward; a pared-down set of solid mechanics and atmosphere common to action RPG's embedded in an action-arcade game. Great co-op fun. Enough depth (via team dynamics) to engage without so much that the action is compromised.

I haven't played through much of it so it might be light on content. I would have preferred random, procedurally-generated levels for better replay value. Probably needs a few like-minded friends to make it worth your while, but if you've got that it probably is.

I haven't played the original Gauntlet so I don't know how this compares, but this seems well-executed and sleek, to me, without necessarily reaching for the stars.

reviewText:
I read a lot of these reviews and a lot are not taking in to account that this game was built to be played with your friends just like in the arcade if your not playing it co-op your not playing it right... HOWEVER Solo is still a great experience considering your can choose between your favorite class and level them all up individually and with VERY good difficulty options.

Playing the game on Normal was great fun. Then bumping it up to hard I almost didn't notice a difference at first, until I all of a sudden realized I was not winning anymore. So I knew something about making it harder was working but I could not figure out what it was. The game does a really good job and making it hard without making it feel like its impossible.

Then there was Unfair mode, still with that same feeling. I feel as if I can manage to get through the simplified dungeon layouts after learning them on normal mode but instantly get shutdown with in the 4th or 5th room. With time I'm sure I will become better at the game and pick up and make my own techniques for getting past dungeons on Unfair mode. I just LOVE how hard the game can get.

A LOT more about this game is great. Despite having the same general dungeon layouts the game has GREAT replay value.
