reviewText:
Alright, this game is AWESOME. It's THAT type of couch co-op where you actually have to cooperate.
While single-player seems to be quite well - though a little bit harder for some classes - multi-player is the bomb. Not only it allows local coop, but online works wonderful. And let me tell you - multiplayer is a blast. You get a couple of friends on skype - and you will have hours of non-stop fun.
And itself it's a pretty good game, though some classes seem to be harder to play/master. Levels are nicely decorated, announcer doesn't annoy you, classes are useful in their own way and generally it's enjoyable. Keyboard works fine, though I yet have to try the controller.
While it seems that Getting 3 shards of whatever" will be pretty quick (the first chapter took 3 of us 2 hours)
date: the replay value is in different classes
recommended: because they differ A LOT. Warrior deals massive damage to tours and fat monsters while elf thins out small crowds of weaklings and mage supports with slowdowns and ignitions. And because of this variety everybody plays differently.\n\nI would say it is DEFINITELY worth the money if you have a couple of friends who'll join you."

reviewText: Great. Even better with friends. Removes some of the ease of early Gauntlets by making each character have unique attacks and defense mechanisms. Further character customization comes from relics which you can choose based on your style. Armor 'upgrades' also appear but seem solely aesthetic and give no stats boost. Not nearly as long as previous versions of Gauntlet.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: No voice or text chat means there is no way to strategize or interact with other players other than running around in circles. The developers said they want to make the game as close as an experience to the original arcade as possible, but are actually using that as an excuse to avoid programming more. If you are standing at an arcade machine with three of your other friends there's nothing preventing you from using your voice. The game is also unforgiving. Even on easy difficulty you should have at least three people in your party or it will be tough to proceed. Getting more people to join you should be simple, but the developers opted for the archaic quick join" feature for multiplayer instead of giving players a list of lobbies. This means that you could click quick join and wait for minutes to join a game not knowing whether anyone is actually playing a public game at the difficulty you selected. All of this equals an unsatisfying multiplayer experience unless you know well three other people that all want to play and have the game. $80 for you and three of your friends to play a game where you can't communicate is a bad deal."

Playing the game on Normal was great fun. Then bumping it up to hard I almost didn't notice a difference at first, until I all of a sudden realized I was not winning anymore. So I knew something about making it harder was working but I could not figure out what it was. The game does a really good job and making it hard without making it feel like its impossible.

Then there was Unfair mode, still with that same feeling. I feel as if I can manage to get through the simplified dungeon layouts after learning them on normal mode but instantly get shutdown with in the 4th or 5th room. With time I'm sure I will become better at the game and pick up and make my own techniques for getting past dungeons on Unfair mode. I just LOVE how hard the game can get.

A LOT more about this game is great. Despite having the same general dungeon layouts the game has GREAT replay value.

reviewText: I've had a lot of fun with this game so far. The characters each have their own advantages and disadvantages to complement their unique play styles. The game also proved somewhat challenging to beat on unfair difficulty. My only complaints are that it's currently a bit too grindy, requiring you to get over 200,000 kills to complete all of the class's mastery pages. Additionally, the devs have yet to implement random level generation akin to the old arcade-style Gauntlet. Instead, there are only three sections of the game, each is broken into 4 chapters. Three chapters in every set of four contain 3 levels each, the fourth containing the boss fight. Each set of 3 levels is mostly the same: the first always a challenge level with keys, locked doors, and monster summoners, the second always an escape level" of sorts with a constantly respawning threat (Death
hoursPlayed: and the third an arena-style level with monster summoners that takes place in one room. Furthermore
voteText: all of the bossfights have the very simplified mechanic of avoiding the boss for a set amount of time until they become vulnerable
helpfulPercent: then attacking them for about 5 seconds before they become invincible again. Rinse and repeat. Despite these complaints
votesHelpful: the game is still a lot of fun to play with friends provided two or more of you didn't want to play the same class. This game is worth it if you can spit the cost of the four pack
votesTotal: but I'd wait for it to go on sale to buy it just for yourself unless you already have people to play it with."

reviewText:
Arrowhead has adopted the franchise from Midway Games and has decided to reboot it.
Not re-iterate the story, not make a sequel, but to reboot it. In order to do so, they decided to go back to the original arcade games from the 1980's and take a few pointer tips for their inspiration of level design.

However, instead of endless dungeons that the originals produced, this game focuses on more of a linear storyline.

Three worlds - One Boss per world
Four levels each -Three stages per level (Explore, Race, Challenge Arena)
Four difficulties - Easy, Normal, Hard, Unfair
Four characters to select, five with DLC - Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Elf, & Necromancer
*Online and Local Co-op with up to three other players!
Different Masteries per character to unlock

Gone are the days of treasure chests and a variety of potions to unleash upon the hordes.
Nowadays we are prone to smashing pots and boxes for gold. You do collect a potion throughout the entire game, you use these to display your special ability in combat. Special abilties can be bought at the in-game store and you can have up to two at once.

Different skins for your weapon and character are buyable as well, but they are just for looks.

Many complain this game is bland, but it is really just inspired by the bland-ness" of 1980's retro arcade games. The look and feel is all intentional. If you enjoy that nostalgia
date:
then the price is worth it.

It is a retro rpg - hack and slash - dungeon crawler.
You either love it or you shame it.

8/10"

reviewText:
I have fond memories of the original Gauntlet. I remember playing the Amstrad CPC version for a whole day, only taking breaks for food. I also had the Gauntlet Legacy games which I thought were ok but too different from the original game. This latest incarnation of Gauntlet does not disappoint. It retains aspects of the original: 4p co-op, overwhelming numbers of enemies and a good dose of humour. It's a great homage to the original with many elements that have been updated to modern standards.

This game surpasses the original in my opinion which is no mean feat. Each character plays very differently. My favourite is the wizard who is tricky to use at first but when mastered can be very powerful.

I've seen some reviews which accuse the game of being repetitive. There is some truth in that, especially when you have to restart a level from the beginning. The action is so fun that I don't mind repeating the same level again and it also allows you to gain more gold and level up your character.

reviewText:
I saw this game as an HD reboot of the old 80s arcade classic.  Fortunately I was wrong.   The arcade classic is there - but its in spirit more than form.   There are still hordes of enemies, gates that need to be unlocked, and food to shoot - but they have taken the combat system to the next level, and introduce encounter and boss stages that bring the game onto a much higher level.   Every player has a learning curve - you need to learn how to be effective with them.  The wizard being the hardest.   Once you start to learn your character however, the game is a lot of fun.    I picked up the four-pack of gauntlet and sent it to all of my old gaming friends.  Multiplayer is a blast.   I only wish we could select the same character .. If I recall you could in the original ..  Red Valkerie is about to die" ...

Before buying this game I checked a few reviews and critic sites.   I would sum up the feedback of the game as "luke warm" ..   Many people cited glitches and crashes as the main problems.   I'm playing version 1.03 (Patch 3) and neither my friends nor myself have encountered any problems whatsoever thus far.

If you played the original
date: Gauntlet II ..  you should love the game and be pleasantly surprised by the additional features.   If you are new to the franchise
recommended: then remember that it is a remake of an 80s original - its not trying to emulate any other game but itself ..  be patient with the character learning curve and I'm sure you too will enjoy it!\n\n2012-12-13 UPDATE:  I play this game casually
hoursPlayed: a bit here and there.  I'm starting to get my character masteries filled out - where you unlock small incremental buffs that accumulate to make you more powerful.  I love the Necromancer update with the Colosseum.  I play this game mostly solo - but when my kids or friends play with me - the game takes on a whole other level.  It scales to the number of players and the boss fights are an absolute blast.  Still unable to select the same character - that sucks  "Blue Wizard is about to die...""

reviewText:
I was extremely pleased to see that an this remake of a classic game did not create a sexpot Valkryie for fan service. She looks similar to the other characters in that she is scarred, she looks strong, and she obviously has some issues in her past.  I fully approve. Her frame is realistic to a warrior while still keping feminine traits, this is how it should be done.

On actual game play; I have only played alone or with friends and I'm not sure this game would be fun with strangers online. It's really funny destroying the food when I'm alone but I can see that being frustrating as hell when trying to co-operate with others, for them and me.

Game seems far, far too short. Hoping more levels will be added at later dates, hopefully for no rediculous fees but really... DLC quest really took the cake for satire humor that we're all pretty well used to. I'm sure there will be DLC in the future, I just hope they aren't too expensive and that they add extra characters and maybe skins as well as levels.

Despite my complaints however, I do recommend this game.  It's difficult, it's challenging, it's funny, it's Gauntlet; even if it is a weak-sauce version of it.

reviewText: Gauntlet is a series of games consist of hack n' slash dungeon crawlers.  The games have been pretty straightforward and enjoyable, and this version of Gauntlet doesn't deviate too far from the formula.  Gauntlet isn't an HD remake of the first game.  It is a modernized retelling, keeping some things but adding in a few new things to change things up---with mixed results.\n\nGauntlet is a decent looking game that plays pretty well.  The game's strongest point is how each character plays.  The four choices (Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf) have relatively unique playstyles.  You'll have to excuse my controller references coming up, but the Warrior and Valkyrie can be most closely associated with button mashers
date: relying more on the face buttons to perform commands.  The Wizard and Elf, on the other hand, are twin-stick" shooters
recommended: relying on heavy use of the right analog stick.  Each character also has special abilities to offer further variety
hoursPlayed: but the most diverse character is the Wizard.  While the other characters are easily accessible
voteText: the Wizard has a learning curve due to the number of abilities he has (in comparison to the others).\n\nThe game still stays true to its hack n' slash
helpfulPercent: dungeon crawling roots.  The game tries to have some kind of story for why the characters are thrust into the Gauntlet
votesHelpful: but it is paper-thin---almost unnecessary.  I know we're supposed to be collecting shards for a sword
votesTotal: but I really just wanted to kill some monsters with my friends.  Now
votesFunny: something that makes this game stand apart from other dungeon crawlers is the lack of a leveling system.  Your character doesn't gain levels (they do gain "masteries
commentsCount: but more on this shortly), and is just about fully equiped with every ability they will ever have.  I find this to be a welcome break, and it helps keep the game accessible to anyone.\n\nUnfortunately, I found there to be more negatives than positives to this game.  The game offers up masteries
column16: which are basically perks that require a lot of investment.  Most of the revolve around killing enemies, but having to continuously play through levels to kill enemies is rather annoying.  If, perhaps, the mastery requirements were lower or if they were shared across all characters (where applicable), I wouldn't be as annoyed with the mechanic.  However, the amount of work and time needed to entirely unlock them isn't worth it, in most cases.  The rewards are so incremental that it makes me wonder why they're there.\n\nSomething that may also help is a stronger level variety.  There are 30 levels in the game.  27 of them are part of 9 standard" levels and the other 3 are boss levels.  When selecting a non-boss level
column17: you are committed to a three-level endurance run that
column18: despite the aesthetic changes
column19: all follow the same formula: 1st level is a "long
column20: standard" level
column21: 2nd level is a "short
column22: environment hazard" level
column23: and 3rd level is an "arena" fight.  Given that the levels are not procedurally generated (a "hot" item in more recent dungeon crawlers)
column24: the replayability falls short.  The bosses aren't incredibly fun to fight either
column25: making them rather underwhelming.\n\nAnother downfall about the level structure is the "hub" area.  After completing either the series of 3 levels or a boss level
column26: all players are transported to the hub area to select a new level or purchase items.  The game offers the players items in the form of relics---which can only be used if potions are collected
column27: or loadouts---which are only cosmetic permutations for the characters.  The relics offer a little more variety to the potions (instead of just "clear the screen of enemies") and the permutations don't hurt the game at all
column28: but relics can never be used on bosses and the loadouts require us to beat the bosses and specific difficulties to unlock (and even then they cost gold to purchase).\n\nThis game also harkens back to the original Gauntlet by restricting the group to one unique character per player.  We cannot all play as Wizards or Warriors in a 4-player group.  I like the idea of having team variety
column29: but forcing it typically leads to a lot of players quitting from a game since they can't play as a character they've invested time into.  However
column31: playing this game with more people is always a good time
column32: and with a recent patch text chat has been made available.  On top of the other tweaks that have happened since the game's launch in September
column33:
it is apparent that the developer's aren't just letting this game settle.  They plan to keep improving it.

Summary
Pros:
Graphics aren't terrible; very likely this game will run on anything.
Controller support
Each character has a unique playstyle
Co-op is fun; online and LAN.
Developers still working out the kinks and making updates.
Cons:
Game is a bit on the short side.
Not enough levels

reviewText:
One of the worst games I've ever played.
Very cheap rip off of the gauntlet franchise.
The gameplay is very linear and boring.
For dungeons they have just copypasted the first map of each dungeon, added few corners and corridors and that's it. Same goes for the monsters. Every level has the same monsters and spawners, but with a diffrent skin.

They should have taken a look at what Gauntlet: Dark Legacy was like and learned from that.
This game is just garbage.

3/10

reviewText:
I like it but I do have a few reservations. It does capture the feel of classic quarter eating Gauntlet - to a point. But, I think it is also trying to be a Diablo type game and it falls short trying to be two things at once.  There is a great C64 game published by EA called Raid on Doomfang. It featured 100 levels and a level designer - good times!

Also, I am puzzled as to why this game is poorly optimized. It runs very HOT whereas games like Kingdoms of Amalur - admittedly not a Cry Engine GPU killer - barely cause a blip in GPU temps.

I am hopeful that either level randomization and/or a leve editor will be added to Gauntelt 2014 to give it some legs. As it stands now, it is fun for VERY short bursts of time. Come on devs, please flesh ut the skeleton?

reviewText:
Are you wishing to find something similar to good old Diablo 2, but with the ability to move with the WASD-keys, aim with the mouse and more or less wave-zombie-survival-like gameplay? Look no further.

Gauntlet is a great game for both playing solo or in a party. Choose one of five classic characters:
Barbarian (aka The Warrior)
Valkyre (aka The Tank)
Archer (-_-)
Wizard (aka Invoker's little bro)
or Necromancer (aka The DLC-chick)
and get into the fight through the vast dungeons full of monsters, traps, TURKEY and GOLD! The more you play and the more you kill - the more powerful you get, opening new bonuses and abilities.

Sharpen your axe and spear, stretch your bow or ....? your spellbook and dive into action!

reviewText:
I don't remember Gauntlet Legends levels being this plain and boring. Seriously, if you want an example of a modern *level design* failure - play this. No juice in them at all, only paper.

Other than that you probably gonna have fun at least for the first 4-6 hrs. After that it's more of the 'perfecting the character play' or learning other characters you haven't played yet.

On high difficulties reminded me of *Alien Swarm* - requires great cooperation, coordinated planning. Anyone who wants to have the same experience once again should probably really get recommended to play this.

-
Buy ONLY when the price if low. Really low. Or find real friends and play old gauntlets.







(http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BEXJppB2BCE fu cking look at this sh it. Basically the main difference: you had LEVEL progress pefore and constant characters, now you have short levels and CHARACTER level\progess, and even that is not that deep.)

I like it but I do have a few reservations. It does capture the feel of classic quarter eating Gauntlet - to a point. But, I think it is also trying to be a Diablo type game and it falls short trying to be two things at once.  There is a great C64 game published by EA called Raid on Doomfang. It featured 100 levels and a level designer - good times!

Also, I am puzzled as to why this game is poorly optimized. It runs very HOT whereas games like Kingdoms of Amalur - admittedly not a Cry Engine GPU killer - barely cause a blip in GPU temps.

I am hopeful that either level randomization and/or a leve editor will be added to Gauntelt 2014 to give it some legs. As it stands now, it is fun for VERY short bursts of time. Come on devs, please flesh ut the skeleton?

reviewText:
Gauntlet is your typical dungeon crawler and if you enjoy mindless hack 'n slash without in-depth elements to it, it can be a decent experience, especially in co-op mode. The game runs smooth and ...

Gauntlet is your typical dungeon crawler and if you enjoy mindless hack 'n slash without in-depth elements to it, it can be a decent experience, especially in co-op mode. The game runs smooth and ...

Gauntlet is your typical dungeon crawler and if you enjoy mindless hack 'n slash without in-depth elements to it, it can be a decent experience, especially in co-op mode. The game runs smooth and ...

Well, the review above pretty much shows my experience with this game. I've replayed the first dungeon multiple times and it just keeps crashing. I've only been able to complete it once and it crashed right after finishing it. I tried different settings, re-installing, verifying cache, killing background apps, etc. The game runs smooth while it works but the constant crashing obviously makes it unplayable for me. I have a decent PC that runs other much more demanding games without any issues so the game itself seems to be the issue. If anyone has any tips to get it to work it would be appreciated and I wouldn't mind changing the review to positive. But for now it seems like that's $10 down the drain.

reviewText:
This could be a fun little arcade co-op game with 3 of your pals.  There's just one issue, it's unplayable with M&K.  Sure they have some keys (the arrow keys for movement), but this game is fast paced and requires some twitch and precision aiming/dodging.  That just ain't happening by using the arrow keys to move.

I don't need the wtf bro it's 2015 get a controller already, it's the future bro.  So save your vapid insipidity.   I'm just  here to inform anyone else out there that, if you don't have a controller, don't get this game.

I'm gonna vote it no, until I get a controller and play it.  I have purchased too many games before checking the efficacy of playing with a M&K.  It will damage my pride, but I think it's time get comfortable with a controller.

reviewText:
Unplayable due to terrible controls.

Fighting and moving are very difficult.  It's hard to get your character to do what you tell it to.  There are a bunch of special moves and combos and such, but you end up doing them in the wrong direction or missing the enemy that is right next to you.

It starts in a tutorial level.  There is one enemy zombie, just walking around in a circle, slowly.  You have to kill the zombie.  It takes 1 or 2 hits.  But doing that will take 5-10 tries and getting the 15 feet to the enemy will require effort.

It is frustrating.

Of note is that I have 0.2 hours into this game, and that is the most of anybody in my friends list.

reviewText:
Challenges can be fun. And Gauntlet has the fundamentals of a great challenge: interesting tools for split-second decision making, and difficult encounters that demand you play your very best.

Unfortunately, there are some awful design decisions and sloppy glitches that spoil what would otherwise have been a classic action game.

First, the pacing: Gauntlet has historically been a very fast-paced game. But the obstacles in this Gauntlet are often extremely tedious. Monster spawners take ages to destroy, and you'll have to do it over and over again. Once you've found the right strategy, you'll just be repeating that approach every time, while hoping that one of the game's many glitches doesn't ruin your attempt.

Among these bugs: Enemies will get stuck, invincibly, inside walls; the player character will get stuck in the world; collision detection screws up frequently; attacks will miss enemies directly in front of you; small elevation changes will render abilities useless (God help you if you try to fight on stairs); your defensive skills will sometimes fail to work; and relics can cause your character to lock up.

Any of these glitches can lead to a cheap death, and that often means losing 20+ minutes worth of progress, since the game's rewards are gated behind challenges like complete three levels in a row on the hardest difficulty without dying once
date:
while your character dies in a split second if you screw up, or the game does.

While Gauntlet seems suited for a quick jump-in, jump-out pace, the level structure actually requires completing several very lengthy levels in a row, which gets very tiring, especially when they consist of the same obstacles over and over. The level design itself is poor, with lots of boring, winding paths, thoughtless blob-shaped rooms, and cheap traps. In one of the randomly-selected sections, there's a room that can trap your character by requiring a key to exit yet not including a key anywhere in the room, or any way to backtrack, forcing a restart.

There are fun elements here, but it's a sloppy product.

/* generic journal_lulz review */

\Day 1://
Woke up in a dungeon. Some dude tried to sell me stuff but I had no money. I see a door illuminated with light. I step inside.

\Day 2://
Stepped into a bigger dungeon. Found lots of gold. What's that? I hear shuffling coming from behind that locked door.  Oh good, I have a key.  Oh, no a swarm of mummies attack.  I kill them all and loot their corpses.  I sure can carry a lot of heavily-weighted gold for one man.

I find a turkey sitting in the old, musty dungeon.  I have no idea how long it has been sitting there.  I say f*** it and eat the turkey anyway.  What's the worst that could happen? I find a doorway that looks like the devil's mouth, so I do what any normal person would do and step inside.

\Day 3://
The turkey is not sitting well at all.  I've pooped my pants and it is running down my leg.  The mummies won't stop and now there are spiders everywhere.  I really don't think I should have eaten that turkey.  I think I'm hallucinating.  I see an apparition appear before me. It is Death, and he is here for me.  I run my ♥♥♥ off trying to get away, but the trail of foul-smelling fecal matter makes it impossible to shake Death. He vanishes from time to time when the smell becomes too much even for him, but he is close on my stinky tail.  I finally manage to find another demon mouth and plunge myself inside of it.

It couldn't get any worse now, could it?

\Day 4://
Stuck in a room with never-ending ghouls, ghosts, and other assortments of the creatures of the underworld.  They seem to be coming from some kind of portal. So I blow it up.  When I do, two more take its place.  So I blow them up too.  Pretty soon, all of the creatures fall before my unwielding power and stenchiness. Gold appears from out of nowhere so I pick it all up. I must have over a ton of gold stored on my body somewhere.

My stomach lurches and makes an inhuman growl. I head for the exit but collapse onto the hard, cold granite floor. The last thing that I hear is my bowels letting loose one final time as the blackness encroaches.

<!--ELF HAS DIED OF DYSENTERY-->

...the moral of the story is never eat a turkey you found in the dungeon. You'll poop your pants.

reviewText:
Awesome if you like the style of gameplay from the original Gauntlet. If you like the preview videos of the gameplay, chances are you'll like the game.

There is one annoying thing, though. Playing Merlin online. You compete for gold with the other players, and he has, by far, the longest cooldown on his dash ability. This means you're pretty much always getting the least gold. He also has more utility, but he has to use a lot more skills to be on equal ground to other characters. If you like challenges he'll be a great character. Seems to have a few OP abilities, but the cooldown on them is long enough to make him boring for me. But if you don't mind slightly longer cooldowns but a lot more options, maybe he'll be good for you. Just be sure to save that dash for getting gold, if possible (half the time it's not possible). Players are brutal on this game when it comes to gold, but it's all in good fun.

10/10

reviewText:
Great game but poorly thought out MP really gets in the way.  Gamplay itself is great though. Some problems that need serious improvements are:
1) The further you get in endless the longer it takes to get to where you were when you start (the checkpoint system/teleporter takes you 19 lvsl at a time).... they could have easily fixed this but never did.
2) A online game browser would really help as of now all you have is quick join which is often plagued with problems (person can start a game then just leave the game running in the lobby and anyone who tries to join a game will be funneled into that game.. essentially meaning one person can effectively shut down the MP for everyone)
3) Other little annoyance is you can't change controller mid game if you play one class with the gamepad and the other with keyboard/mouse you have to back all the way out, essentially meaning you can't regroup up with your current group unless you get lucky and quick join takes you back with those people.

Last big problem that I wish they would fix is that the controls can't keep up with how fast you eventualy have to be to survive, this is mostly with the wizard on a keyboard and mouse..  the difficulty ramps up to a point where as fast as you have to 'flick' the element buttons to change spells... even if your skill gets to the point where you can effortlessly change and reload spells fast enough to survive in the higher difficultes (i.e. floor 200+).. after a certain point that is much lower than how difficult the monsters get... many times the buttons won't register if you hit them too quickly... apparently in an effort to protect against cheaters using macroes etc... basically kind of ruins the game.

Overall game is one of the better ones out though today in terms of action /dungeon crawler with 5 really different classes.  Aside from the aforementioned problems its a great game and definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
This 2014 edition of Gauntlet is a game I want to like, but that's simply impossible. It's a tedious, monotonous game with serious design problems. The game recently got polished into Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, but the problems remained.

Conclusion: looks good, but not worth of any money. Maybe, if you get it for free, or as a part of humble bundle. Otherwise, no.

Regrettably, this game is not fun to play at all.

After 4 to 5 first levels the game starts to repeat itself. First levels are fairly enjoyable, but after that: nothing new. Controlling game characters (4 different + 1 dlc) is not rewarding, because most of the time your character is very hard to spot from the screen. That's because of three of the worst design flaws: walls obstruct your view, the viewpoint (camera) is zoomed out way too far away from your character AND the levels have very few light sources.

Playing the game makes you wish you had binoculars and a flashlight pointed at the screen.

How about multiplayer mode? You need a friend for that, because there is never anyone playing multiplayer otherwise. Once you get online with your friend, you will experience even more design flaws. You think you cannot get motion sickness from a game? I dare you to try this one on multiplayer mode. Have a bucket next to you when you try. I mean, what were the devs thinking? On single-player you have to strain your eyes to be able see your tiny character on a dim screen, and on multiplayer mode the screen jumps and jolts around making sure you'll vomit, or at least get a headache.

Even if I pretend I can endure the flaws I mentioned, the boring map design and clearing a floor after a floor from the same enemies over and over again is just not worth the time. It is very sad to give this game thumbs down, because I really loved previous Gauntlet games, such as Gauntlet: Dark Legacy and the original Gauntlet and Gauntlet 2. Yes, even the original Gauntlet is less monotonous than this one. At least the original Gauntlet had proper level design and a feeling of progress in the game.

reviewText:
The game is mediocre at best.  I never played any of the previous Gauntlets so I never felt any nostalgia people wrote in their reviews.  I felt the game had a lot of potential but it fell flat.  The graphics were decent and made the game looked very interesting in the screenshots.  However, the game was extremely repetitive.  You literally grind variations of the same 3 path dungeon 3 times (so you play each path 3 times) then you reach boss.  There is absolutely no replay value.

I played D3 when it first launched and I thought it was fast.  Well, this game is even faster.  However, there is incentive to grind in D3 for better gear.  Here, you grind to level up your skill but really you just get a longer duration or deal more damage with your skill most of the time.

A lot of people said this is a coop game and I imagine this might be the reason.  I played single player and felt the game was really boring the whole time.  The only real replay incentive is if you want to beat at the highest level of difficulty (there are easy, normal, hard and unfair).  I bought this with a discount so it didn't hurt me as much but I rather have spent it on another game now that I know this one is bad.  I really hated the voice acting for the elf.  The voice acting fits a thief character where he sounds a bit sly.  I honestly imagine the best class would be wizard with complex skills... but I really am not interested enough to want to find out.

reviewText: As a player of the original Gauntlet series, this game sucks. It sucks because the attacks are made to be annoying to use and not straight forward(like the previous ones) so that you have to always place your self specificaly or take some kind of time to think about it to actually hit the enemy. Some people may say that I just want a simple minded game, but again, I come from where the previous games had three attacks(melee: activated when you touch an enemy, light/fast: fast weak ranged attack, strong/slow: slow hard hits.) The only person that has some resemblance to the original formula is the sorcerer. Another MAJOR down side is that there is no level system like the previous three. Why would they think that you won't need levels in this? Just the same damage output and input the whole damn game? That turns the whole damn game into a Kiting play(Kiting is when you run away, shoot, and repeat), and kiting is not suited for this kind of game. To all who disagree, I emplore you to go play the originals(not seven sorrows, it sucks. Still better than this though). They replaced leveling with gold, which means that gold will eventually become useless. People could argue that xp eventually becomes useless BUT that takes a much longer time to cap(meaning max level) than to get enough gold for everything, plus experience doesn't have a constant spot on the screen to remind you of it. Again, Just go play Gauntlet Legends or Gauntlet Dark Legacy, and then play this, you will most likely see where I am coming from. This sequel just makes me sad to have seen, to know that they ruined" it with the designs they chose to go with.\n\nSome may wonder why I have such a low play time

reviewText:
An interesting but weak reboot. Some design decisions are nonsensical. Networking is atrocious, which makes online play a moot point. Upgrading is slow and takes a long time for no good reasons, and upgrades are incredibly minor in most cases.

The characters are annoying yet somehow unintentionally funny in how cliche they are. It reminds me strongly of a game that was made way back in the day to spoof Gauntlet, known as Get Medieval. Strangely, each character class does not control best with the same control scheme. Using mokey for the elf is a serious advantage, while using anything but a controller for the other classes is a mistake. The wizard is not playable with mokey, so don't even.

Bizarrely when playing online each player must choose a different class. They fixed that ♥♥♥♥ when Gauntlet 2 hit the arcades back in the day, there's no excuse for this complete retardation.

Worth it on sale maybe, but not otherwise. If you own Diablo 3 you will never have a reason to play this game. Slightly recommended.

The game is pretty fun, BUT the camera kinda sucks hard. I get that its supposed to run between everyone, thats Gauntlet. but it shouldnt be so... behind? reviewText:
Why it doesn't suck: It looks pretty good for a co-op dungeon crawler at this price point, it plays allright and feels fair and balanced.

Why it sucks: It is not Gauntlet. Level themes are fairly mundane compared to the old school Midway versions that I was hoping this game would be. It seems there is nothing in terms of character progression other than movesets that really don't feel unique from playthrough to playthrough. Short.

Rating: a box of Cracker Jacks /10: its definitely not as good as what you remember (or even resemble it) but its filling and the multiplayer is the prize in the box. Nothing beats shaming someone for shooting food even though it seems like this is the only connection to the original Gauntlets. But the value is all gone once you realize that the campaign is drawing to an end and the achievments left to unlock are just grindfests to kill monsters and collect pointless loot.

reviewText:
I went into this game hoping to experience the fun of the original or at least some small part of nostalgia for an arcade classic.  It didn't happen.  I played this with my brother for some 2 player co-op.  My brother played the warrior character and found it to be just a boring spam-fest of pressing the attack button.  No thrills to be had there.  So, on to the wizard I go. This character is the complete opposite of the warrior in terms of difficulty.  It has an interesting mechanic similar to that found in the Magicka games where you can combine elements of Fire, Ice and Lightning to make different spells.  The problem is I found that the normal fireball spell was sufficient for most encounters. The other spells just end up prolonging battles.  Swapping spells on the fly is a little cumbersome and was another reason why I spent the majority of the time in fireball mode.

The gameplay and tactics can be a bit unforgiving.  If you don't perform perfectly than it can be hard to recover.  Worst of all is there is no checkpoint system.  If you die, then that's it, back to the beginning of the level you go.  For those seeking a challenge, this is a good point.  For just trying to play through the game on a normal difficulty, this is just frustrating.

Overall I wasn't as impressed with this game as I was with a very similar game, Hammerwatch.  Hammerwatch has the same top down Gauntlet-esque adventure and battles and even sports the pixlated 8-bit graphics.

My personal opinion, I'd say give Gauntlet a pass unless you pick it up on the cheap when it's on sale or really want a challenging top down adventure to play co-op with your family and/or friends.

reviewText:
Two very hun...<ELF NEEDS FOOD!>...gry thumbs-up!

Oh, nostalgia. Brings back memories of ditching Ritchie Ponderosa's roller-skating party to waste $10 in quarters at the arcade there in the 80's. Boy was my mom ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

Great evolution of the franchise makes the additions a welcome advancement to the series since inception.

/* generic 11/10_lulz review */

Shot food, died of hunger. Came back to life on top of spikes and died again instantly. 11/10

/* generic journal_lulz review */

\Day 1://
Woke up in a dungeon. Some dude tried to sell me stuff but I had no money. I see a door illuminated with light. I step inside.

\Day 2://
Stepped into a bigger dungeon. Found lots of gold. What's that? I hear shuffling coming from behind that locked door.  Oh good, I have a key.  Oh, no a swarm of mummies attack.  I kill them all and loot their corpses.  I sure can carry a lot of heavily-weighted gold for one man.

I find a turkey sitting in the old, musty dungeon.  I have no idea how long it has been sitting there.  I say f*** it and eat the turkey anyway.  What's the worst that could happen? I find a doorway that looks like the devil's mouth, so I do what any normal person would do and step inside.

\Day 3://
The turkey is not sitting well at all.  I've pooped my pants and it is running down my leg.  The mummies won't stop and now there are spiders everywhere.  I really don't think I should have eaten that turkey.  I think I'm hallucinating.  I see an apparition appear before me. It is Death, and he is here for me.  I run my ♥♥♥ off trying to get away, but the trail of foul-smelling fecal matter makes it impossible to shake Death. He vanishes from time to time when the smell becomes too much even for him, but he is close on my stinky tail.  I finally manage to find another demon mouth and plunge myself inside of it.

It couldn't get any worse now, could it?

\Day 4://
Stuck in a room with never-ending ghouls, ghosts, and other assortments of the creatures of the underworld.  They seem to be coming from some kind of portal. So I blow it up.  When I do, two more take its place.  So I blow them up too.  Pretty soon, all of the creatures fall before my unwielding power and stenchiness. Gold appears from out of nowhere so I pick it all up. I must have over a ton of gold stored on my body somewhere.

My stomach lurches and makes an inhuman growl. I head for the exit but collapse onto the hard, cold granite floor. The last thing that I hear is my bowels letting loose one final time as the blackness encroaches.

<!--ELF HAS DIED OF DYSENTERY-->

...the moral of the story is never eat a turkey you found in the dungeon. You'll poop your pants.

reviewText: Gauntlet is well...a pretty simple experience. The eponymous gauntlet is full of hordes of monsters and you have to destroy them, along with the summoning stones that spawn them, in order to reach the heart of the maze while collecting gold and eating/destroying food along the way. The complications arise around how to complete that straightforward task. The choice between warrior, valkyrie, elf, or wizard consists of more than a set of strengths and weaknesses; each represents a unique playstyle, from hack and slash to twin-stick shooter. It's that variety of tools, not the diversity of problems to solve, that lends the experience its interest. Joyful hours are spent not just killing the small number of unique enemies spread over a miniscule three environment types and learning the rudimentary story which is implied more than actually told, but in finding new and inventive ways to do so. The heart of Gauntlet has little to do with anything other than answering the very arcade-like question of how to reach the exit with your limited number of (skull) coins.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Grandpa dungeon crawler is back. If you never played a Gauntlet game, imagine Diablo but only the dungeons and caves and none of the open world or towns. Each character has a different play style, the most unique being the wizzard who plays like the game Magicka where you combine spells into different attacks. This also features slight RPG elements, for example the more crates and urns you break you level up a perk that gets you more gold in them. In the main portal room there is a shop that let's you buy and upgrade relics that give you special abilities and also sells cosmetic items. Whether you are playing co-op or solo this is a fun game.

reviewText:
Classic Gauntlet has made a return and done so with just enough nostalgia and a good set of upgrades that this game feels like Gauntlet 1 and 2 but with an edge...and a story.  Eh who needs the story...endless hordes of monster slashing fun is what this game is all about.  So if you enjoyed the original quarter eater then you should fall right back in love/disgust with this one.

Pros:
Classic characters with new abilities
Fast paced and full of action
Rune system which makes use of collected gold
Co-op is near lag free and tons of fun

Cons:
Being the last person in your party and being stuck playing as the warrior
Story elements are weak and out of place
The game is very short(12 levels)

Prospects:
Steam Workshop support may be added in the future

reviewText: If you like hack-n-slash and twin sticks and you liked the old arcade gauntlets, you'll love this remake. Play the right way using a gamepad, sit back, and enjoy this love letter to the old school. I've played all of the gauntlet games from gauntlet 1 to seven sorrows, and this gauntlet is the best of the series. I love that I can play gauntlet as a pure hack-n-slash (warrior), twin stick shooter (elf & wiz) or as captain america (valkyire). Don't expect a diablo or a mouse driven action rpg, this game is arcade action with lite rpg elements. Must buy for people who enjoyed any of the gauntlet games.

reviewText:
Was tempted to give it a thumbs up - Really solid game with some solid points. I do  however have far too many gripes to warrant this

The Good:

- Great sound track -

Musics great!

- New meets old styled gameplay -

I like the varied moves, big cooldown styled attacks and the way they did the Wizard and Elf. Feels like Diablo 3 gave some inspiration to this game and it's very much welcomed.

- Local Multiplayer mixed with online-

Can you say awesome? Because more games need more local multiplayer ESPECIALLY on the PC.

The Bad:

- Progression is non existant -

The relics are neat, but im a bit disapointed with the gear. Getting more gold? Meh. It wont give me a bigger axe or make me hit any harder or put me in some shiney new armor that does something neat for me. I was hoping for deeper rpg elements.

- Incredibly short -

Games far too short. Can be cleared too quickly.

- Dejavu with dungeon elements -

Playing through a few specific dungeons I felt they dragon aged" it. By that I mean they copy and pasted parts of other dungeons into it.

- Weak multiplayer elements -

Game encourages you to take items and food from other players.

- Few minor bugs -

I got a crown knocked off my head and it landed on a part of the map I couldn't get at. Thanks game.

- No colour palette swapping -

"Red Wizard needs food badly" "Blue Warrior is about to die" - I miss the colours.. Having four warriors or four wizards would have made this better
date:
why not? :(



All in all I'd say pass on this unless it's on a 50%+ sale. For 5-10 bucks you'll get a decent ammount of fun for a day with a couple of your friends for local multiplayer
hoursPlayed: non-existant RPG elements really make this a tough one to purchase at the now asking price of CDN$ 21.99\n\n"

reviewText: This version of Gauntlet is an ode to the original arcade and NES versions of Gauntlet. It feature the four heroes from the originals with the respected colors. It holds the classic arcade style hack and slash that inspired games like Diablo, with the additive of armor and relics that give the game a little bit more depth and a sense of progression. Ontop of that each character has it's own unique feel and move set, not a single character is alike in this game and it gives a very unique challenge of overcoming each stage with certain limits and abilities. It does not have many levels, but you will find that is because you build up in difficulty through them, starting in normal to unlock your first armor pieces that you will use to complete the levels in hard more, and so forth. As it is right now it has a ton of replayability and is very fun for multiplayer. There are not many levels in the base but for an asking price of 15 dollars you really get your moneys worth, and hopefully future DLC will add more levels and armor to the game.\n\nAll in all I give this version of Gauntlet a 8/10. It's got rather well placed music, a very decent challenge even on normal difficulties and a nice sense of progression.

reviewText:
Gauntlet is a fun and balanced romp through vast hordes of enemies. BUT you already knew that! The new twists to gameplay are welcomed even by older players who remember Gauntlet since it's 1980's release into arcades. Controls are excellent even on mouse keyboard. The art is fun and not overwhelmingly detailed so much that it detracts from tracking your character on the screen.

Setbacks:
-- Difficult Wizard controls. It's Guantlet, not Magicka !!! (Please change or option to change)
-- Local play with 4 players running in all different directions can be frustrating. However, this is how the 19080's version worked as well.
-- Missing the cool announcer voice and some absent popular sayings.
-- Cannot have multiple of the same class of characters . I.E. No multiple elves in different colors... :(

Pros:
++ Fun for all
++ Easily can run on lower end systems
++ Shooting the food!
++Treasure
++ Boss battles can be interesting
++ It's Gauntlet!

reviewText:
Gauntlet is an incredibly enjoyable co-op hack-and-slash dungeon crawler that is highly reminiscent of the original, while offering Arrowhead’s own spin on the foundations previously set. The game plays well and is a lot of fun with friends, co-op definitely being the recommended way to go, although is still viable as single player. It’s certainly a little lacking in places, especially when it can occasionally feel a little repetitive, but overall this doesn’t hinder it too much. The game looks and feels great, and is something I would not hesitate recommending to fans of the hack-and-slash dungeon crawler genre.

Summary:
+ Fantastic class revamp and disparity.
+ Enjoyable combat and gameplay.
+ Nicely stylised visuals.
+ Good difficulty variety.
+ Decent boss battles for the most-part.
- Some level mechanics feel too gimmicky.
- Levels can feel a little repetitive.

reviewText: This game is everything I was praying it would be. The four characters available have differences in their playing styles which makes the game worth playing multiple times. The enemies are difficult at times but this forces the player to get creative rather than fall into the same murderous trance over and over again. Each floor contains something different from bosses, to death incarnate, to just flat out treasure troves. To make things better, the game contains many upgrades in the form of relics and you can even customize your hero with new armor and weapons in the shop in the hub room. This game is made even more fun when you play with your friends, the teamwork element makes strategies more fun and gathering more loot than your friend is always a fun contest. I cannot wait to see how this game progresses. It is a fantastic reboot and is more fun than most games I've played this year.\nSo yea 10/10 :)

reviewText:
Though lacking the grand scale found in Legends and Dark Legacy as well as the simple yet engaging combat system found in those iterations of the gauntlet series, this game ranks head and shoulders above its predecessors, and ARPGs in general.

The classes are complex and a blast to play, each class with a unique playstyle that brings the characters to life, giving them a unique role in multiplayer and replayability in single player.

Personal favorite is the wizard, who uses a magic system not dissimilar to Magicka's system of magic, though simplified and  streamlined. Honestly, all the classes are a blast to play, but the wizard stands out to me as how wizards in ARPGs should be implemented in ARPG's: mental acuity combined with skill.

As mentioned above, it doesn't have that grand scale of Dark Legacy or Legends, opting for the classic dungeon crawler vibe it helped to create. The humor lightens up the atmosphere and creates a jovial atmosphere that makes multiplayer great, and with a good complement of friends, you could be looting with the best of them.

Speaking of which, the game allows you to use gold to purchase gear and loot, as opposed to items and levels in previous iterations, giving it immeasurable depth.

Chances are, you'll find something you'll like here, and 20 dollars is a great price for a game of this caliber. Don't pass it up!

reviewText:
A remake of a classic arcade game that ♥♥♥♥♥ my wallet all through my childhood and teen years. Updated with more fluid combat, relics, classic rpg elements, witty banter, and yes, delicious turkeys. I preordered this game as soon as I head about it and let me tell you this, beats the absolute ♥♥♥♥ out of Diablo 3.

My Rating?
100/10

Why?
This game is incredible.

Pros:
-Great gameplay
-Challenging for both solo play and cooperative play
-Lots of gold
-Lots of dead people trying to kill you
-Delicious food
-Same screen coop for when you have a friend over and want to show them the game but don't want to be that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥      that just sits there playing it while they watch you.
-The characters each have their own sense of humor and dialogue
-Questor the scottish elf archer
-The warrior's name is Thor!
-Having to escape Death. Literally. Death incarnate will chase after you in certain levels.
-Classic mode, for when you want that truly nostalgic arcade feeling
-Lots of giblets

Cons:
Not Applicable

reviewText: This plays similar to the NES/Arcade original, which brings back great memories of playing with my old man back when I was just a kid.  This game is plain fun.  I started with the warrior, but have found that the wizard's spell casting system is an excellent cerebral addition that makes Gauntlet really shine for me.\n\nI'm running this on a 2012 Macbook Pro with bootcamp running Windows 7.  I have to turn the resolution down to half and play in a (fairly large) window to keep the fps up.  It hiccups from time to time, but it's overall playable in a window.  Not so much in fullscreen. Turning the VSync on keeps the framerate locked at 60, which is just fine by me.

reviewText:
So I'm here to talk about this new game, Gauntlet, an-
HEY! Stop shooting the food!

Gauntlet comes back from the glory days of the arcade after a few moderate attempts to revive the franchise.

What's presented to us here is an interesting take on an old-school idea:

Grab your friends (Online or offline), choose between four classes, enter the arena, and slash/shoot/blow up your way to victory!

Just...stop shooting the food please.

Gauntlet is centered around fun with your friends. From the beginning you will be facing hordes of enemies that can be dealt with better as a group than by yourself. While nowadays some may draw a comparison to Dynasty Warriors or other hack-n-slash games, the different game mechanics presented with each character help spice things up.
Like Magicka? the wizard might be up you alley.
Like a stick shooter? Pick the Elf
Wanna button mash your way to victory? The Warrior and Valkyrie might be the choice for you.

With reviews coming in for about 6-7 hours of completion time, Gauntlet seems to be a little on the short side of the gameplay factor. And yet, it will probably have you coming back for more, as you try different characters and relics combinations that add more variety for the game.

For its price point, it seems like a very fair deal as it's not trying to market itself as a AAA title, but more of a fun afternoon/night time fun with your friends after work.

For those who want some nostalgia with a new kick to it, or those who have never heard of Gauntlet!

reviewText:
Great value buy.

Double the fun in coop-mode where you walk the fine line between team work and utter selfishness.

This is good old-fashioned arcade fun. Just don't expect a deep item or crafting system. Although there is some degree of character progression it just isn't the focus of this game.

reviewText: I was partially worried that this game would only be good if you wore a pair of nostalgia glasses while you played, but my goodness! It is amazing, it is the best, I love this game, its so true to the original series. The swarms, the gold, the potions, the abilities, everything about this game is challenging and face paced! Even though I have died like 75 times, I am still laughing and having fun with this game. Its frustrating, but the light hearted comedy keeps it from really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off. Also, this game only gets better with friends. I am sure co-op will have you begging for the Warrior's Key-ness too!
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Besides some performance issues, either with the bloom, shadow, FXAA implementation or something else -still haven't pinpointed the culprit- that I hope gets fixed in the near future, the game has been entertaining so far. If I have to give it a rating, it would be an overall of 7/10.\n\nI never got to play the original Gauntlet games, and I think I played some Dark Legacy at some point but I don't remember much of it. What this game sure reminds me of is the Dark Alliance series on the PS2 and Xbox and I had a great time with those, just straight, arcade fun hack-and-slash action. I just hope that this game doesn't die quickly since it relies heavely on online co-op, if that happens then ... it'll be a thumbs down most certainly, cause when you're playing it alone, it's not that novel, it doesn't cut it in this day and age when it comes to content and you end up wanting to play something more fulfilling like Dragon Age, Path of Exile or other dungeon crawlers.

reviewText:
The good part of this game is the fun dungeon crawling experience and hard hitting enemys unique class specific abilitys and upgrades through the main hub shop.

The bad part is the camera tracking, its so annoying instead of tracking you and each player individually the take it back to the old school co op days where the camera tracks all playes. So if you have a player that doesnt keep up have fun trying to progress. If you can get past that part or have friends to play with this game should be a fun experience.

Note: this game is not very good for AMD cards and its a short game.

Rateing 8/10
Good graphics.
fun gameplay.
upgradeable characters for each class.
bad camera tracking.

reviewText:
This is nothing like any gauntlet game I've ever played.

It's like those Marvel top down beat 'em up games from the ps2/gamecube era.
Lots of button mashing, lots of grunts to kill, lots of different ways to do it.

I love the game but I think that the classes are poorly balanced, but since it's a co-op that doesn't matter too much.

I like how achievements" unlock skills and abilities
date:
probably the only time I care about achievements haha.

I highly reccomend this game if you like top down beat 'em ups with SOLID controls. They're flawless.


Warrior:
Plays like he should
recommended: press the X X X and the Y Y Y. His B spin attack is invincible and gives you some extra range. I dislike how you have to charge his charge
hoursPlayed: but the charge jump attack is good even if it takes a bit of practice to get the range right. His heavy attack deals a LOT of damage
voteText:
very useful.

Valkyrie:
I like her dash attack more than warrior's bull run (although I like the warrior's bull run) her shield doesn't seem that useful since hordes are usually how you die
helpfulPercent:
but she does a good job of being different than the warrior so kudos.

Easily the most broken of the classes

but there is a bit of a skill cap so he's not entirely braindead (just monstly brain dead)

I hope you liked magika because this guy is magika as ♥♥♥♥. Good luck using him. He's easily my favourite to play as but he is by far the hardest class to play. He has a TON of spells and they all have individual cool downs so poppin' off damage can be easy

but you're going to need to memorize all the spell inputs before you can even be mediocre at wizard.


All in all the game is really fun and I hope you guys check it out and enjoy it."

reviewText:
I have been a huge fan of Gauntlet for a very long time, and when this game came out I was very excited to try it, after warner took Mortal Kombat under it's wing and it's done so well I had high expectations for this game, and unfortunately NONE of them were met.

The game tossed out every previous good idea in the last couple installments so things like 3way shot thunder hammer those no longer seem to exist.

The Classes you can choose are severely lacking with only a selection of 5 [4 from the start]

The customization is nearly non existant and what little you do have is set on the top shelf" so you're quite aware the game is going to be exactly the same it is when you start it and nothing really amazing is going to happen.

The Potions have been changed into something else
date: now they are solely for using your items you can buy which you're only able to carry 2
recommended: not only that you can no longer stock pile them so if you don't use them the level you find them
hoursPlayed:
you lose them. You can also only carry so many of them as if they're really all that great anymore.

The level design is extremely stale and as soon as you start the game you get the notion "I'm going to see a lot of the same S***" through this game"

In conclusion when I got this game I was pumped after all the years I'd been trying to get a better computer to run it properly and in all the years I've played video games I've NEVER played a game I completely hated and felt cheated
voteText: for buying it and I've enjoyed some games people really cannot stand. If you're a fan of the older games
helpfulPercent: especially the last couple releases like "Dark Legacy" and "Legends" this is not the game for you
votesHelpful: you will be SEVERELY disappointed. If you're a fan of the orginal you're SLIGHTLY better off
votesTotal: but I STILL do not recommend it
votesFunny: What makes games like Mortal Kombat so good is they kept what made the games great initially while adding content to the games that improved it
commentsCount: what makes this game bad is they tried to dumb it down all the way until it was simple like the originals
column16: and then tried to make it more "real" which is dumb for such a game that was built for the kind of "cheesie goodness" kind of feel\n\nMy comment: Why doesn't Warner Brothers just put funding into a "Gauntlet Dark Legacy HD" that plays online and add content to that? That would have been MUCH better."

reviewText:
Easy = Normal
Normal = Decently Hard
Hard = Memorize the area and events to win, lose half the time to one stupid enemy managing to get a last hit.
Unfair = Impossible

Colliseum seasons will have you breaking your head into your keyboard; they are ridiculously hard for the only reward being pointless clothing for your character/bragging rights. The only other way to get cool items is beating the regular campaign levels on harder difficulties, but the only actually cool items require Unfair difficulty which is legitimately UNFAIR.

So what do you have left for this game? Oh the actual regular gameplay... well.  Its sort of boring, and I only go through it to complete challenges, get new ♥♥♥♥, progress in the game, etc. The replay value? None. reviewText:
I very much recommend this game. Though I do caution players. I played all the previous and original arcade versions and this game takes the trophy so far. It's a very simple concept as well. Run through the levels, try not to die, and beat the boss. You can cool artifacts and armour on the way if you're lucky or good enough.

This game does not skimp on difficulty. When it says hard, it means hard. I haven't even tried unfair with my friends. But you do need comms and communication to succeed.

A definite recommendation from me

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game, but it lacks in content and unlockables.  It's also very short.  There are 3 zones, each having 3 levels and 1 boss; this amount of content feels like a beta at best.  I tried playing it a bunch of times to rekindle the love of the old Gauntlet games, but no luck, just another hack-em-up dungeon crawler that's boring as hell.  Hopefully the devs will get a clue and release more levels, unlockables, and rewards; until then, I wouldn't bother.  Or wait until it's $4.99.

reviewText:
When I saw the announcement for this I was ecstatic. My friends and I eagerly awaited release, and even when it got pushed back started guessing that they were making more content or enhancing the game.

I guess in our minds it was to be Gauntlet Legends  with a retro style option (like the Sonic 2d/3d retro/modern crossover game) We were all pretty let down.

The wizard controls were probably the single greatest disappointment. They render the character a punishment to a party of 4 players. The fact you can have only 1 of each class hurt too>

All in all, very let down, and really hoping they patch/upgrade the game for free to rectify the short comings. Would love to see a Gauntlet game like Dark legacy brought back with procedurally generated maps, questing system, item collection, unlockable characters/classes, a leveling system with player chosen stat increases, DLC expansions, Workshop support, character appearance customization (minor would be plenty) and better character controls.

If you are looking for games like this one, get Hammerwatch. It has better balance, larger maps, more classes. and the same feel graphics and mob-wise.

reviewText:
Gauntlet is a fun game ot play...but it has alot of cons to it.... for example:

-If your playing with other people...you share the same screen so its fustrating when you want to go one way but u cant becuase someone else is going another way. It makes exploring the game a bit fustrating.
-Looting; When you collect gold coins u all share the gold but if someone dies that person loses there pocket change. Which would also allow someone to pick it up after u drop giving that player who picked it up more money.
-Classes; okay...I have to be honest....being a melee class...really sucks....Because the Wizard and the archer are the only characters that can get any kills and stay alive while the melee classes could barely get any kills in. Melee classes also die alot if they dont have any space to run back and forth to the monsters...run in, hit once...run back... thats it for melees while the ranged classes will kill everything before it even touches them. another diffrence is, melees are really good at taking spawners down...so thats a plus for being a melee...right..? not really the spawned mobs will just suround u and you'll die if your not careful.

However, i would still give it a try. Expecially if you got friends you can play with.

reviewText:
I am a long time fan of Gauntlet - back from the pop a quarter in the game at the Mall Arcade era. This is a wonderful true to the game update of the system. Alas there are some bugs. My son can not get it to open at all  - per the forums this is a common problem.  And using a keyboard - the navigation is tricky.  I still can't see how to use potions whcih would be helpful in the race from death.  Even at Easy level you can shoot food and potions.  The wizard is complicated on the keyboards with a shift left click shift spacebar sort of spell pattern ( While using Wasd and mouse to flee  for your life). Good update - not great and not as seemless as I would like.

Multiplayer helps greatly with survivability. Be careful you dont move too far away and get your partner stuck - yes still has that issue from orginal game. And be careful when you go somewhere if it is a one way trip or not.

Curious how play is with a controller vs a keyboard. If my son can ever get his up - then we will see.

reviewText:
Alright then, looks like update from 29 Sept actually fixed most of the issues with the game (aside from 1080p settings on some machines, still requires editing of the config file :| ). So, now I can finally recommend this game!

What is Gauntlet? It's a coop action-rpg dugeon crawler with tons of enemies, traps and all that stuff.
You have 4 classes to pick and every class has a pretty unique gameplay style. Which is pretty cool.
Game play perfectly better with a controller rahter than a keyboard.
And if you want to play alone - this is probably not for you. WAY more fun to play with someone.
So, yeah, pretty awesome coop action rpg thingy. Not recommended for single player experience, friends only :)

reviewText: Great casual game to pick up for 20 minute romps with three good friends. The levels are designed in such a way that you can easily break up your play time if needed or play through the night just as easily. The character classes have interesting unique play mechanics and controls that make switching from class to class much more fun that a simple change of appearance. In general, a solid game for those that enjoy a little co-op with a lot of replay value.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I played Gauntlet 2 on the original NES for years upon years and I feel like this game is a faithful remaster of that formula. For the asking price of $20, I have no buyers remorse and have had an enjoyable experience with the game thus far. If you're looking for a loot-driven dungeon crawler, this is NOT what you want; this game is more about cooldown management and circle-strafing while mowing down hordes of respawning enemies whilst attempting to gather gold and destroy enemy spawn points. As for loot, there are cosmetic options that you can earn in the game with gold purchases, and relics that you can purchases and upgrade for limited use during the levels. The four classes are quite distinct and I've found a few good combos for 2-player co-op. It seems like a simple game at first, but there's enough depth lurking here to keep you busy for some time.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If you like the original Gauntlet or want to see what a properly rebooted series should play like, look no further than this current interation of the arcade classic.  Each class plays completely different, which makes each role feel useful in multiplayer.  Add in an enjoyable Mastery system and Skill shop and you've got one hell of a dungeon crawler. Hopefully Arrowhead Game Studios will be as fruitful with DLC as they have been in the past ( I hear they just release the 753rd Magicka DLC pack ).\n\n---Gauntlet™ is well worth the full price; buy this.---

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game.


Simply put, if you're a fan of a guided path with secrets and gold to discover, have a local or online buddy to play with, AND  love some randomly generated dungeons where Death himself follows you around as you scramble for gold and survival- you'll love this game.

Solo goers don't be afraid, this game is great for you, too!

It' s intense, it's fast paced, it's fun. I don't need loot and a giant world to explore, I just need a Gauntlet to run and a weapon to do it with. This game provides, and, my girlfriend even loves it. A+ work.

reviewText:
Very fun game. Very Gauntlet feeling. Really brings back the old school arcade action hack n slash fun.

Pros:
- Up to 4 players at once
- Smooth, fast paced combat
- Replayability via harder difficulty modes
- 4 very different classes
- Fun graphics. Easy to look at and enjoy
- Great music
- No crashes (yet)
- Only $20.
- Works amazing well with a controller

Cons:
- Limited replayability based on actual content. This game needs a map maker, or endless levels.
- 4 very different classes that are very poorly balanced with each other. Some are clearly more OP than others, which means the competitive" aspect results in the same classes coming out on top 99% of the time for the end of level bonus.
- Hackers (hopefully they can fix this soon. At the very least
date:
ban them and remove them from the global scoreboard.)
- Buggy class abilities cause inconsistancy and unreliability when you need them to work as they are intended.
- Obviously designed with paid DLC in mind to keep the game more replayable. (the ending credits even hint at it).
- Works pretty badly with keyboard and mouse. Awkward and limiting.

Over all
hoursPlayed: the game is very fun. A great game to jump in for a short to mid duration action spree with your friends. If this had been at the arcade
voteText: I would have easily spent 20 bucks in quarters just trying to beat it. So yeah
helpfulPercent: its worth the buy."
